reviewText: With "Good Night, and Good Luck" George Clooney (yes, you read that correctly, GEORGE CLOONEY is the writer and director of this overwhelmingly-positively-reviewed film) delivers a riveting account of a crucial chapter in 20th Century American history and, in the process, firmly establishes himself as a major force behind the camera as well. The crisply paced, tautly scripted docudrama recounts the events of the mid-1950s leading up to acclaimed CBS journalist Edward R. Murrow's (David Strathairn) decision to stand up against fiery Senator Joseph McCarthy, who was out to rid the country of communism. McCarthy's seemingly reckless behavior, in which he condemned individuals without giving them a fair trial, angered Murrow and his producer Fried Friendly (Clooney) into action. The resulting few episodes of Murrow's show, "See it Now," found Murrow on a personal, patriotic crusade to challenge McCarthy and rid America of his callous persecution.Set almost entirely inside the smoke-filled, pressurized newsrooms at CBS, Clooney's assured picture moves at a breakneck pace. Cinematographer Robert Elswit miraculously recreates the black-and-white look of that era, giving the film an added air of legitimacy. And while Clooney and co-screenwriter/producer Grant Heslov wisely chose to use stock footage of McCarthy instead of finding an actor to fill his shoes, they couldn't have found a better Murrow than in Strathairn, who delivers his lines with heroic conviction. Clooney's stellar ensemble cast also includes Ray Wise, Patricia Clarkson, Robert Downey Jr., Jeff Daniels, and Frank Langella.As his live television production of "Fail-Safe" showed, George Clooney has an interest in recreating drama with a sharp, fifties/sixties-style sensibility. He also has a desire to express his very distinct--and markedly liberal--political views. This revisiting of the 1954 television confrontation between CBS newsman Edward R. Murrow, still venerated as an icon of activist journalism, and Red-baiting Senator Joe McCarthy gives him the opportunity to fulfill both ambitions simultaneously. Happily, "Good Night, and Good Luck"--the title repeats Murrow's signature sign-off--isn't just a stirring paean to courageous reporting that challenges the powerful when they mangle the truth or abuse their position (the message that Clooney certainly intends to communicate to the contemporary media); it's also a crackling good story, told with style and economy.The approach that the director and co-writer and producer Grant Heslov bring to the tale is tight and focused; not much happens beyond the confines of the CBS broadcasting studio and a bar where the newsmen hang out. (The rare exceptions are the office of William S. Paley, the head of the network; the halls of Congress; and the apartment of two staffers who are secretly married--against company policy.) The portrayal of Murrow is equally limited; we learn nothing of his personal life. It's his dedication to getting out the truth at all cost--he knows full well that McCarthy will use his customary tactics of personal vilification through allegation of communist sympathies against him--that dominates. The script, drawn largely from the record in recreating the broadcasts but naturally more speculative when it comes to off-record conversation, portrays him as a man of unquestioned anti-communist attitudes whose opposition to McCarthy involved disagreement not with his goals but with his methods. (It precedes the assault on McCarthy himself with a treatment of Murrow's investigation of the case of Milo Radulovich, who was dismissed from the Air Force because of his family's supposed communist ties--a program that symbolized the effects of the senator's tactics on innocent individuals.) It also shows him as a strategist aware that he had to choose his battles carefully (thus his refusal to be more open in his support of anchorman Don Hollenback, a protégé of his who was attacked by McCarthy partisans in the media) and circumspect in his dealings with Paley. Murrow doesn't come across as a plaster saint here; his uncertainty and concern for the safety of himself and those who work with him is subtly demonstrated as well as his passion for honesty and principles. And the pain he feels at having to compromise himself by doing entertainment programming like "Person to Person" to insure continuing network support for his serious "See It Now" program, even when its controversial character threatened to sour advertisers, is also shown (sometimes in humorouds tones, as when he has to conduct an interview with Liberace).In painting this portrait of Murrow Clooney is fortunate in having David Strathairn on board. A journeyman actor whose excellence has often graced good films in supporting roles, he here embraces the limelight with a performance of great restraint and power, conveying both the man's courage and his self-doubt with the most modest of gestures. It's not mimicry but a performance that effortlessly holds your attention, while never turning showy. Clooney himself does a nicely self-effacing turn as Murrow's ever-supportive producer Fred Friendly, and Frank Langella cuts a figure of imposing strength (and no little duplicity) as Paley. The rest of the cast pales by comparison, but Ray Wise has a few moments as the nervous Hollenback, as does Jeff Daniels as a network exec who's often delegated to do Paley's less savory tasks. Among the staffers, Reed Diamond, Tate Donovan and Robert John Burke stand out. One must also note the elegant black-and-white cinematography of Robert Elswit, which suits the period timeframe perfectly, as well as allowing Senator McCarthy to portray himself in television footage from the fifties--a device that will wisely deflect the charge that his character has been misrepresented by any actor's portrayal of him, as well as allowing him to convict himself in the film just as he did in real life. (Period footage is also employed in the "Person to Person" sequences, to fine effect.)All this praise shouldn't be taken to mean that "Good Night, and Good Luck" is without flaws. A subplot involving those two newsroom employees, Shirley and Joe Wershba, who keep their marriage secret because of company regulations is given entirely too much time, even though the characters are played well enough by Patricia Clarkson and Robert Downey, Jr. (and are designed to act to a certain extent as audience surrogates). A linking mechanism involving cutaways to a singer crooning songs into a microphone in an adjacent studio is simply intrusive, though the songs are obviously designed to comment on the action as well as providing period flavor. And on the broader canvas, complaint could certainly be raised about a general slimming down of the record--a lack of full historical context, a simplification of events involving not only Murrow's personality but the whole anti-communist movement of the period (not all of which, after all, was unjustified).But to dismiss the picture on those grounds would be to condemn the "Good" as the enemy of the perfect. (The same criticism of failing to tell "the whole truth" could be leveled at "All the President's Men," too.) This is a stylish, absorbing account of an episode in American journalistic history that has as much to teach us today as it did Murrow's audience half a century ago.
summary: "We will not walk in fear of one another."

reviewText: I will start with a disclaimer: I really like David Strathairn, I think he's a remarkable actor who absolutely deserves more acclaim. I've liked him since that white water rafting movie with Meryl Streep, so, my review may be biased.I love this film -- it seems to improve with repeated viewings. The message is there -- people in power using fear (of communism, and in 2006, of terrorism) to attack civil liberties. The movie itself is very subtle; for myself, I've grown accustomed to being clubbed over the head by directors trying to get my attention. GN&GL; is quieter, more reasonable, showing that men of courage need not be strident, they simply need to stay strong in their convictions.I thought the special features, although somewhat brief, really added to my enjoyment of the story. Without the director's commentary, I would not have known that Srathairn and archive footage of Murrow were in the same camera shot -- Strathairn is that good. Highly recommended.

reviewText: George Clooney's second attempt at the triple threat of filmmaking (actor/writer/director) that in 2005 got him and the film Oscar nominated 6 times (and winning none) sorta to me after five years didn't seem all that impressive. The true story of 1950's CBS journalist Edward R. Murrow's battle against the mass accusation of communism brought by then Senator Joseph McCarthy should have been alot more enthralling than this. Clooney definitely has the power to bring in some great A-List actors (Robert Downey Jr., Jeff Daniels, Patricia Clarkson, Frank Langella), but the story as a whole seems bogged down by pacing and too much stock footage used of the actual broadcasted interviews and original people involved. Murrow here is portrayed by character actor David Strathairn, who no doubt is very well at his craft, but lacks any real punch or drive like the real Murrow showed over fifty years ago. As a history lesson, it does educate the viewer in the now-absurd public witchhunt of the 1950's, but at times tends to entertain more like a school lesson than a motion picture. Disc includes a very low-played commentary with Clooney and fellow screenwriter/actor Grant Heslov (who's acting credits date back as far as Clooney's with an almost equally embarrassing early resume....he did a "Facts Of Life" with George too), a doc on the film (that's in color) with some of the real life people left alive, and a trailer that I swear makes this movie look alot more exciting than it actually was. Clooney does prove he can direct a movie, but I still think with this story that gripped a nation he could have been played a bit more....gripping.(RedSabbath Rating:6.5/10)
summary: Television Broadcast News' Golden Age Seems A Tad Lackluster Here...

Clooney definately has an appreciation for history in black and white.  Remember his CBS tv version of FAIL SAFE?It's a return to classic black and white filmaking, a return to a movie about GROWNUPS and a return to authentic historical storytelling.  As you watch this film and study the cinematography and camera angles, you can't help but feel remeniscent of watching the immortal classic, CITIZEN KANE.Despite the fact that it's a story of CBS's Edward R. Murrow's crusade againt Joseph McCarthy, it's message to those who would seek to persecute and wage their own personal agenda at the expense of the American people is just as relevant today as it was in the 1950's.

reviewText: Of all the embarrassments in our nation's history, the blatantly fanatical anti-Communist witchhunt of the 1950s conducted within the halls of Congress by Joseph McCarthy, the junior senator from Wisconsin, must rank as by far one of the worst.  But there was one man, legendary CBS newsman Edward R. Murrow, who dared to call the senator on it.  It is this clash of titans that is richly detailed in glorious black-and-white by director, co-writer, and co-star George Clooney in GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK (named for Murrow's trademark sign-off phrase on his nightly news broadcast).David Strathairn portrays Murrow down to almost the exact physical appearance and speech clip of the legendary newsman, as he and CBS news director Fred Friendly (Clooney) make the momentous decision to put the reputations of both themselves as journalists and human beings and the reputation of the CBS television network on the line, and confront the senator and his high-handed brand of demagoguery (utilizing authentic film footage of McCarthy from that turbulent time).  As Clooney and producer/co-writer Grant Heslov show, Murrow managed to undercut McCarthy's fanaticism and credibility by using the senator's own words and his lack of proof against the vast majority of Americans he accused of having ties to the Communists.  The film also showed how this was perhaps the very first example of television, which was largely still in its infancy, displaying the ability to shape the minds and opinions of people.  Frank Langella does an extremely good job of portraying CBS chief executive Bill Paley; and the excellent ensemble cast of Robert Downey Jr., Jeff Daniels, and Patricia Clarkson compliments this superb movie.Even though GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK is set in a time more than half a century in our past, it still feels shockingly relevant, which is almost certainly why Clooney decided to take this subject matter--this, and the fact that his father was himself a prominent newsman in Cincinnati.  We see the conflicts between reporting the truth on the news and concern for a network's profits and concerns over being the target of political investigations, and we realize that what was true back in the early 1950s still remains true in our present day with respect to dissension to an increasingly unpopular and deadly Iraq escapade.  This is, by any definition, the mark of politically liberal filmmaking, but so be it.  It is the right kind of film in the right place at the right time, just as Edward R. Murrow and his team were the right people in their time.  This kind of bravura filmmaking is the kind that Hollywood did so well throughout the 1960s and 1970s, and what it should begin to do again today.

reviewText: Fear gripped America in the 1950s. By that time the Soviet Union had turned solidly from ally to enemy. The Cold War had begun, spurring backyard bomb shelters and nuclear disaster preparation films. People lived in constant terror of "The Big One". "Communism", already on the list of "evil" words since the 1930s, became a downright threat. In the midst of this, Senator Joseph McCarthy (R - WI) claimed that communists had infiltrated various levels of American government. On various occassions he brandished lists of suspected individuals which varied in number from 57 to 205. These accusations, never accompanied by proof, nonetheless led to resignantions and firings and the fear that America lay vulnerable. Somehow McCarthy managed to put himself above criticism; even President Eisenhower never disparaged him publicly. Many of McCarthy's accusatory hearings were broadcast on the very new medium of television. Millions viewed them.Enter journalist Edward R. Murrow, one of the unsung pioneers of early television. Murrow had garnered a squeaky clean reputation following his coverage of the World War II London blitzkrieg bombings. His opening line "This... is London" crystallized the horror of the destruction. Murrow went on to work for CBS doing news and special interest stories. He set the standard for journalistic integrity as well as for celebrity interviews. But, most famously, he outright challenged Senator Joseph McCarthy. This film celebrates the stand that CBS and the staff of "See It Now" took against the "Second Red Scare".The film's black and white tone and the realistic settings place the viewer squarely in the 1950s. An "as it happened" feeling pervades the movie's 93 minutes as antiquated television technology comes to life in the studio sequences. Even social details, such as how CBS employees address their boss and the status of women in the workplace, receive subtle but detailed attention. The pacing remains deliberately slow. Most of the tension and drama gets revealed in intense facial expressions and "come to my office" episodes. This likely matches the historical reality. Filming sequences emphasize the nature of what Murrow and staff probably went through emotionally. They threw out a challenge and then tensely waited as if "The Big One" could drop right on their studio at any moment after sign off. This movie aims for ultra-realism in every respect. It wouldn't have worked in color.Murrow's first scene shows silhouetted smoke streaming out of his mouth and nose. Apparently he always had a cigarette (which unfortunately led to his death by lung cancer in 1965). Then he delivers a speech to a Broadcasting Convention that condemns the use of television to entertain and insulate the public. The speech doesn't conclude until the end of the film, when Murrow walks off screen accompanied by silence, a symbol that he remains unappreciated for his efforts. The challenge to McCarthyism begins as Murrow questions the discharge of Milo Radulovich from the Air Force on grounds of communism. Producer Fred Friendly, played by George Clooney - who also directed - receives a stern warning from two colonels. Scared but not deterred the crew broadcasts the controversial piece anyway. Then Murrow directly attacks McCarthy which leads to McCarthy's rebuttal and Murrow's final response to the Senator. These programs are historically credited with hastening the downfall of McCarthy, at least in the eyes of the public. Many thought McCarthy's attack on Murrow, reproduced with original footage, damaged the Senator more than the Newsman. Unfortunately, Murrow and Friendly pay the price for thier integrity in the end. The film's main narrative ends on this relatively sour note.David Strathairn's portrayal of Murrow is mesmerizing. Though we never really see anything of Murrow's private life, Strathairn's performance nonetheless conveys a strong sense of a deep and a complex individual. His inner intensity bellows.In the end, "Good Night, and Good Luck" comes off as a movie about journalistic integrity and the courage to stand up to authority gone wrong. It does not stray from politics, and some may not agree with its message. Regardless, it definitely gives a taste of the values of traditional journalism and broadcasting as it highights one of the greatest moments in television history. Viewers can absorb this depiction and use it as a benchmark for today's journalistic standards.
summary: The alleviation of fear through media...

reviewText: "Goodnight and Good Luck" is shown in gorgeous black and white.  i would see the film again just to enjoy the cinematography.however, beyond aesthetics, i think another reason for the use of b&w; was to emphasize the filmmakers' view that the controversy depicted was a matter of 'black and white' in the figurative sense.  indeed, at the beginning of the movie, Murrow is portrayed as saying something like, ~i don't believe every story has two sides; and, besides, the other side has had years to present its case {maybe; but, they didn't get 5 seconds to do so in this movie -- gc}.~i don't believe Murrow (or any other honest journalist, for that matter) believed that any story has just one side; i don't believe he ever said it does; and, even if he did, the makers of this movie are well aware that, based upon the revelations in the Venona papers and corroborating revelations by the successor organization to the old KGB, there certainly were lots and lots of shades of grey to the whole episode.see, for example, the very anti-McCarthy cold war historian Thomas Powers's concession that much of what McCarthy *originally* claimed (ie, that the State Department was shot through with Soviet Spies, the Truman Administration knew this, and that they were dealing with the problem silently, without letting the public know what was really going on) was largely true (contrary to the film putting the words into Murrow's mouth that "99%" of the people McCarthy was accusing were innocent (never mind its slyly trying to make it seem as if Alger Hiss were innocent of spying)).see: http://www.nybooks.com/articles/118http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_mccarthyhttp://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10F16F9355E0C7B8DDDA90994D0494D81http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/venona/intercepts.htmlon his sunday morning talking heads program, Chris Matthews said he had reservations about a film that was so one-sided.  but, after seeing it, he realized this film is not about what happened then; rather, it is about what's happening now.  that is, about the ways in which dissent is being equated with disloyalty.  (for just one example, the very name "Patriot Act" implies that its opponents are, well, unpatriotic.)but, in a subsequent show, aired the day of the Oscar awards ceremony, Matthews said "the problem with Goodnight and Good Luck" (as a candidate for Best Picture) is that this movie makes it appear "as if the other side was making it all up."  (quotes to the best of my recollection.)contrary to the implicit claims of this thoroughly dishonest movie, the other side had no need "to make it all up".  that Joe McCarthy was a nasty drunk and a scoundrel is not in dispute. but, nonetheless, the substance of his original charge is largely true, contrary to this movie's 'black and white' misrepresentations.
summary: the most shamefully dishonest movie i've ever seen

reviewText: During the early 1950s the United States of America valued conformity over honesty and integrity--a social lockstep driven by fears that the Soviet Union had infiltrated American government and society and sought to bring our society crashing into chaos. As the decade progressed, a number of politicians played upon those fears to their own greater glory, and few played harder than Senator Joseph McCarthy, who shocked the nation when he claimed to have factual evidence that numerous branches of the government were overrun by communists and communist sympathizers.Over the past decade or so a number of historians and critics, Anne Coulter among the latter, have attempted to rehabilitate Senator McCarthy's reputation by noting that there were indeed communist infiltrators at work in the United States government. This was doubtlessly true, but there are several problems with this pro-McCarthy argument. Chief among them is McCarthy himself. His accusations were not based on fact and were strewn with misinformation, and he showed a marked tendency to level them against two types of people: those who could not fight back and those who dared to criticize him. If McCarthy ever did manage to expose a communist it was by dumb luck only, and by 1954 even the members of his own party--including President Dwight Eisenhower--were openly disgusted by his behavior.GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK is the story of how Edward R. Murrow, possibly the single most respected reporter of his era, exposed McCarthy for what he was via a meticulously prepared news program. In the wake of this broadcast an outraged public turned against McCarthy and thus gave the Senate the public support required to end his reign of terror.  At the same time, it is also the story of television's role as entertainer ultimately undercut its role as news medium--and laid the destructive seeds of the "news as entertainment" format that today typically overpowers serious journalism.It is in many respects a fascinating film, its script drawn from the actual words of the actual people involved in the Murrow telecast.  It is memorably directed by George Clooney and remarkably performed by an ensemble cast that includes David Staitham, Robert Downey Jr., Frank Langella, and Clooney himself.  The black and white art direction and cinematography is brilliant, truly capturing the look and feel of the era; the pace is rapid fire; and it offers a series of pointed warnings about political bankruptcy and public expectations of television that ring true in no uncertain terms.Unfortunately, it also manages to ever so slightly miss the mark.  This is partly due to the film's divided intent: by refusing to focus specifically on either McCarthy or the issue of broadcast news it manages shortchange both.  It also errs in its use of considerable archival footage, which leaves us to wonder if we might be better off watching a documentary on McCarthy and Murrow instead of GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK.  But the ultimate problem with the film is that gives zero context.  We are told nothing of the tenor of times, given no clear idea of what made McCarthy's claims seem initially viable, and indeed given no clear idea of what those claims actually were. We are simply given to understand that he is a danger to democracy and shown actual film footage of McCarthy to prove what we are assumed to already know.In the end, I have to say that it is always a good thing to be reminded of McCarthy. He stands as a warning to us against those who would play upon our fears for the sake of their own power.  It is also always a good thing to be reminded that "finest hour" events in television news tend to be few and far between largely because of the commercial, entertainment-oriented nature of the medium.  But GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LOOK isn't entirely successful in making its points in either direction.  The DVD includes a making-of documentary that is reasonably interesting and an audio commentary that is largely spurious.  Recommended, but primarily for those who already have enough historical knowledge to fill in the gaps.GFT, Amazon Reviewer
summary: "We Cannot Defend Freedom Abroad By Deserting It At Home"

reviewText: There are times when a rational voice is needed. During the early 1950's the airwaves were filled with Senate hearings on Communist espionage activities in the US and those who were working as believers of communism or its agents.Senator Joseph Raymond McCarthy of Wisconsin began a televised investigation into the Soviet threat on American soil.  Unfortunately, noble pursuit of truth can become sidetracked.  Perhaps, Senator McCarthy allowed the fame of his crusade to override his reasoning.  Of course, his tendency to hard drinking was also a factor in his eventual fall from popularity and senatorial standing.This excellent film tells the story of Edward Roscoe Murrow, the CBS newscaster, who decided to take on the most powerful political figure of the day.  Clash of the Titans-indeed!Television, the strange box in the living room of American homes with its flickering black and white images, became the battleground for these titans.  Those who had these boxes watched the saga unfold.George Clooney brings vibrant life to this American story as its writer and director.  He tells it in a compelling manner which grabs your attention and holds it for the next ninety-three minutes in its black and white format.David Strathaim as Murrow is one fine piece of casting.  He is a fine actor with an impressive resume.This film was nominated for 6 Academy Awards, 4 Golden Globes, and won the National Board of Review Best Picture Award.  It is a remarkable film.If you want to read an excellent novel about Senator McCarthy, then check out--The Redhunter by William F. Buckley.  It is also available in audio format from Amazon.Below is the last statement from the famous March 9, 1954, SEE IT NOW broadcast:"The actions of the junior Senator from Wisconsin have caused alarm and dismay amongst our allies abroad, and given considerable comfort to our enemies. And whose fault is that? Not really his. He didn't create this situation of fear; he merely exploited it -- and rather successfully. Cassius was right. "The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, but in ourselves.Good night, and good luck."

reviewText: In this film, David Strathairn IS Edward R. Murrow. I remember these CBS shows, and Strathairn has Murrow down pat. That's the movie's main positive point. On the other hand, Clooney is as Irish as paddy's Pig, and Fred Friendly was as Jewish looking as they get. They should have cast a real Jew in that part for realism (maybe Ed Herrmann). Also, Frank Langella did a decent job as CBS Head William Paley, but looked NOTHING like him. These criticisms aside, the movie perfectly caught the tenor of the times, and using the female singer in a studio setting to bridge the scenes was brilliant. If you were alive in 1954, it takes you back. If not, it shows you what the world was like then. Beautifully acted by all (even those who were, in my opinion, miscast). Well directed by George Clooney, and filmed in black-and white to set the proper mood.

reviewText: GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK is a brilliant piece of film making, a film that recreates a period in our history when gossip mongers and fear exploiters took the lead for a terrifying few years that threatened to extinguish civil rights forever.  Not unlike now!  And that is one reason this film carries so much resonance: the story of the bravery of popular news reporter Edward R. Morrow (David Strathairn) and his associates Fred Friendly (George Clooney), Joe and Shirley Wershba (Robert Downey, Jr. and Patricia Clarkson), William Paley (Frank Langella) and the crew at CBS is one that begs for re-creation in the way the news is reported, analyzed, and serves the rights of the public to be truly informed.The story is the 1950s McCarthyism Communist Hunting that terrified the country unchecked until Morrow et al challenged the Senator's accusations and methodology by simply quoting the statements McCarthy made in the television series See It Now.  Morrow and his associates did not elect to smear McCarthy: they instead elected to bring to the public's quivering attention just what the sick mind of McCarthy was doing to innocent people. It was an act of bravery on Morrow's part and on the part of everyone connected with See It Now.George Clooney continues to impress as a quiet, subtle voice who doesn't seek the limelight for his brilliant mind, but rather uses it to enter the arena of emerging patriots - the good kind.  He wrote the script with Grant Heslov after much research and investigation and then gathered a gifted crew of actors (including himself) and directed the film using the atmosphere of black and white photography (credit cinematographer Robert Elswit) in the almost exclusively interior claustrophobic set of the television station to give the ring of honesty that pulsates this story to its powerful end.  Strathairn is brilliant as Morrow, but then so are all the cast members in this ensemble effort.GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK is an immensely entertaining film  on every level, but the fact that it is released in such a realistic fashion at this particular time in  the nation's precarious history makes it a film that should be seen by everyone. The DVD added commentary by not only the writers and actors but also the people still living and the children of those who aren't is informative and sensitively poignant. Lightning can strike in the same place twice.  Highly Recommended.  Grady Harp, March 06
summary: A Powerful Film That Pleads for a Return to Meaningful Journalism

reviewText: This movie was much less than I expected, most importantly because the characters were flat and hard to care about.By the time Murrow took on McCarthy, many peoples' lives had been affected by the senator's tactics and any of those stories would have done more to illuminate the consequences of a climate of extreme terror than this dry, somewhat monotonous film. Murrow stands in stark relief as the only brave man willing to stand up to McCarthy, juxtaposed with a couple and a fellow journalist who stand in for "ordinary people" (fearful, unable to cope with the pressure).If you are looking for a civics lesson and a morality tale of the bravery of the lone hero, you'll like this movie. If you are looking for emotional intensity or being lost in a story, you will not find it here.This movie is contemptuous of television for having failed its potential as a source of information and education for the American people - more like a newspaper. Perhaps many viewers interested in this film share that expectation, while others, like myself, also like complex characters and a good story. If a film/TV program did all of these, it would get 5 stars. This is far from the ideal, hence the 2 stars.

reviewText: Whether you are politically liberal, conservative, or somewhere in-between, "Good Night, and Good Luck" does a great job of capturing that period during the 1950s when all it took was an accusation -- substantiated or not -- to throw any American's life (and his/her family's) into a downward spiral.  That's bad, no matter what party you belong to.  For me, choosing Edward R. Murrow to put a microscope on that time, and show the financial and political forces behind every message put out via American media (even today), was a brilliant choice.  Not only because Murrow had the spine to speak out on behalf of average Joes, but also because he was a victim of slur attempts himself.Of course, this movie is as much about today as the 1950s.  The environment of fear propagated by Senator McCarthy's anti-communist excesses back then is a fair analogy to those who today bring up 9/11 anytime they have a chance to heighten fears, which they then claim to protect against.  Although events have since proven them to be incompetent and deceitful as protectors, they have again demonstrated how easy it is to use such fear-mongering to turn people against each other for the gain of a powerful few.  To its credit, this movie captures that, as well.The acting here is good across the board, but David Strathairn, as Murrow, and Frank Langella, as CBS head Bill Paley, are far better than anyone else in this film.  Clooney gets very good marks as the Director (and creator), but his acting here is nothing special, and Robert Downey, Jr. is wrong for his part.  Downey is good in many roles, but they would have been better off casting a lesser-known character actor in his role.  All in all, though, it's very well done -- and every actor in it should get a medal just for the all-too-real smoking scenes.  A young person today might think the film exagerates the smoking, but I'm just old enough to have witnessed similar work environments in my youth.As for the DVD, I was very disappointed that it has no actual footage of Murrow.  The "Making of..." Special Feature is pretty funny, and it is interesting to hear from Murrow's son and some of Murrow's actual staff.  Still, Strathairn does such a spot-on job of portraying Murrow that I went directly to the Special Features after watching the film, certain that they would show the real guy...but, no.  Thus, to make it more fun, I recommend that when you get this movie you also try to get another DVD showing the real Murrow -- just so you can watch Strathairn, then watch Murrow, and see how perfectly he (Strathairn) captured the journalist.
summary: Great Movie, But The DVD Is Just OK

reviewText: I was quite disappointed. Director George Clooney aims for a historically accurate portrait of the 1950's and CBS-TV News' confrontation of Senator Joe McCarthy's anti-communist Senate hearings, and the characters here are as dull as stone face mugs ripped from an old history book. Historic accuracy is never as exciting as the real imagined thing, and these characters are cemented to their historical perspective. One, upon entering his first scene, might as well be wearing a sign reading, 'I WILL SOON BE A TRAGIC CHARACTER'. Clooney has polished his accuracy to a black and white dull shine that reflects his own fascination with the film's detail. The inclusion of a couple in the newsroom who harbor a secret, and are given considerable screen time, adds nothing but dramatic dishwater to the story. Frank Langella offers a fine stony portrait of legendary CBS executive William Paley, and David Strathairn as Edward J. Murrows has a closing speech on the future of television that is stirring. But if you so much as have seen a History Channel documentary on the McCarthy hearings, this film is a bore.

reviewText: Certainly one of the best pictures of 2006 (in fact, my personal choice for the best picture that year) or any other year. A superb film that was particularly relevant for the political climate at that time, but just as relevant today. The film recreates the famous interviews between legendary CBS newscaster Edward R. Murrow and Senator Joseph McCarthy. The one line from the film that continues to resonate is "Don't confuse dissent with disloyalty." Clooney makes all the right choices as a director - filming in black and white and using actual footage of Joe McCarthy instead of an actor, he beautifully renders the paranoid climate of the time.. His use of silence is also noteworthy. A faultless ensemble cast (including Robert Downey Jr., Patricia Clarkson, Frank Langella, Jeff Daniels, and Clooney himself) is headed by David Strathairn's impeccable performance, which captures Murrow even down to the rhythm of his speaking voice. Not to be missed.

reviewText: "Good Night, And Good Luck" should be required viewing for the many Americans who are opposed to politicians who "manage" the news, who remember the McCarthy era or for some of us who lived through Watergate. Directed by George Clooney who also plays the character Fred Friendly, this film is about Edward R. Murrow's (David Strathairn) valiant fight-- along with considerable help from the courageous people at CBS Television, including William Paley played brilliantly by Frank Langella-- against the witch-hunting Senator Joseph McCarthy in the 1950's.Shot in black and white, the film has the feel of a documentary; all of the scenes with McCarthy are actual footage from that era. The message of the movie is obvious: we always need an unfettered, free press. It is one of the tenets of our society that keep us free.Mr. Strathairn is believable as Murrow; Mr. Clooney is outstanding, both as an actor and director. Mr. Bill O'Reilly opined in a newspaper article a year or so ago that if the liberal Mr. Clooney continues his attack on the current administration, that his acting career would soon be over. Apparently that prophecy has not yet come to fruition.This is a great movie, one for all seasons.

reviewText: George Clooney is known for being liberal. I'm just the opposite -- I know better than being liberal. Does this affect this movie? No. This is a must see movie.This movie starts off running, and when it ends, you can't believe it's over already. It's done in black and white, which adds to the effectiveness. The acting is great (especially Frank Langella), and Clooney wisely uses McCarthy's own video footage. It also has humor at the appropriate times.My wife and I weren't sure when we saw the description referring to Joseph McCarthy, but this movie is not either pro- or anti- communism. Rather, the focus is on the freedom of exchange of thoughts. This movie promotes freedom of the press, but also shows the dangers of a reckless press as well.I may be the only person on the planet to think this, and George Clooney might put me on his enemies list as a result, but I would recommend a double feature of this movie and Ben Stein's Documentary "Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed." Both deal with the need for an open exchange of ideas and not silencing opposing views.

reviewText: George Clooney manages to succeed directorially in a clever, pared-down film about the McCarthy-Murrow feud.  Much of it is mock cinema verite, which works because of the right-on cinematography, the terrific art direction, and the clipped, no-nonsense dialogue.  The B&W; effect works great,setting not only the historical dimension of the story, but metaphorically as well:  Murrow is able to beat his rival with the black and white facts: something nearly impossible to do today owing to the spin masters and myrmidons that head mainstream news media. Even the length of the film, less than 90 minutes contributes to the straightforward, sub-plotless story: a film that can be viewed like a news report.  The props, sets, costuming, haircuts are hyperealistically accurate and Frank Langella does an excellent turn as William Paley.  Seeing both the simulated footage and recreated footage of some of the 'hearings,' it is interesting to note how politicians seemed to have a candid, truthful manner in front of the TV camera, perhaps because they hadn't yet mastered the medium, or that there was even a medium that needed to be mastered.Today, a McCarthy-type would need only lose about twenty pounds, get better tailored suits, firm up his sagging chin, and take some voice lessons, and voila, people would never suspect he was a foolish, lying bum. Wait a minute!!!! They have already done that and it worked--at least for five years or so.

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: A brilliant American film for the 21st century. One more film on McCarthy, you might say. Yes indeed. But this one is different. Different because it is in black and white and it is a real smoking factory : politically correctness is forbidden. Different because it is not about the cinema but essentially about television, CBS. The real fourth power of the media : the power of journalism reinforced by the power of images. This television produces news programs that become the 21st century gospels. This power is absolutely enormous. And yet it is not CBS that brings McCarthy down, nor Murrow. It is McCarthy himself who brings himself down when he decides to react to Murrow on television and rebut him. In other words he falls in the trap laid in front of him and is unable to cope with this medium : he appears like what he is, a bigot, and he attacks someone who is beyond doubt in the wide public, a gospel writer as I have already said. Then McCarthy is doomed. This film hence shows something most people ignore on the old continent as well as on the new continent. The USA, like any human society, contains both good and evil because good cannot exist without evil and vice versa. But the USA, like any human society founded on the belief that individuals have rights and are fundamentally free as individuals and as citizens, will contain evil by its own efforts because good is necessarily stronger, even if at times it takes a few years to get around an obstacle and get into a dominant position. It is true some damage may have been caused during the period when evil had the upper hand, but good will push that evil down and aside sooner or later. Unluckily in such a society evil will find its way back up one day and will have to be pushed down again. But that is democracy and to believe that good, provided we all agree on what good is, can triumph once and for all is just as narrow-minded as the belief that communism had triumphed in 1917 once and for all. History has proved how wrong such a wiew was.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, Université Paris Dauphine, Université Paris I Panthéon Sorbonne
summary: Exactly what the USA are all about: freedom!

reviewText: Rarely before have I felt so completely immersed in the goings-on of a film, much less one that took place over two decades before I was born.  This film crackles with such integrity and attention to the moments that it portrays, that I found it hard not to join in on the conversations taking place on the screen in front of me.  In short, this films does not lecture the audience, it includes them.Not one human being can say that their life today does not bare the effects of the events that George Clooney's highly engaging films depict.  But it is not only the struggle to bring down Senator McCarthy that this film is presenting.  It is also a reminder that television and broadcasting have always been and will always be an enormous determining factor in the outcome of any and all major world events, and that it is a tool to be wielded wisely.  The figureheads of this film knew that.I applaud Clooney not only for giving us this marvelous entertainment, but for presenting at a PG-rated level.  This is a movie that should be shown to intelligent children as an important and often overlooked history lesson, and as an advisorial tool on the power of media and it's potential for abuse.Terrific performances, beautiful vocal jazz soundtrack, and direction that may instantly land Clooney as high in the ranks of movie makers as he already is in the ranks of movie stars.

reviewText: "Good Night, and Good Luck" is a brilliant period piece and re-enactment of a series of history-changing events.  George Clooney's direction is wise beyond his years, and the the cast is brilliant.  For all that intensity, however, the movie has just a little too much of Edward R. Murrow's famous ice-water in its veins, and when the last 10 minutes lag behind the setup of the first 80, there's an audible let-down.  While the movie is a can't miss in terms of films you ought to see, it manages to just miss film immortality by a narrow margin.The ensemble cast is led by David Straithairn, who's been turning in quietly great performances for years as less-than-noble characters in places like "Dolores Claiborne" and "Eight Men Out" and "The Sopranos".  His Murrow here is most assuredly not an imitation, not a case of an actor just reading somebody else's lines.  His job is to inflate Murrow's original words into something suitable for the big screen, without crossing the line over into melodrama or sounding like an actor playing the governor at Colonial Williamsburgh.  His "off" moments, when the TV cameras stop transmitting but director Clooney continues to show us Murrow in the darkened studio, are similarly filled with Strathairn's audible thoughts.The use of archival footage to portray McCarthy and Roy Cohn, juxtaposed against Strathairn's red-hot chilliness, keeps the events firmly grounded in reality, without a hammy actor playing McCarthy as a black hat, or some Harrison Ford type playing Murrow as the Patron Saint of Journalists.  Indeed, Murrow's lack of superpowers is shown when he's unable to save his doomed broadcaster friend, Don Hollenbeck, from the rantings of a right-wing media watchdog.Comedy is provided in a post-modern way, as Strathairn silently conveys Murrow's frustrations at having to ask Liberace, during the TV interview program "Person to Person", about why he's not yet taken a wife.  I saw this movie in a sold-out theater, and the laughter in this scene nearly drowned out the dialgoue.  Also funny is the presentation of an authentic '50s cigarette commercial -- indeed the whole movie is wreathed in smoke so thick that you'd think the visual effects team should get a Best Supporting Actor nod for outstanding portrayal of cigarette fumes.The rest of the cast is full of distinguished actors from film and TV... Robert Downey Jr., Jeff Daniels, Reed Diamond (late of "Homicide"), Frank Langella (evidently playing Christopher Plummer), and even Alex Borstein of "Family Guy" (you can almost hear her whining "Peeeter" in her early scenes).  If there's a problem to the story, it's that the secondary characters, with the exception of Langella as a tormented William Paley, never generate much spark beyond the face- or name-recognition.  When the main story ends, the movie drags on for another 10 minutes wrapping up loose ends among the guest cast.  The end of the movie can't sustain the intensity of the first 80 minutes.The McCarthy/Murrow story remains an important one in today's world, in the same way that the retelling of the Salem witch trials echoed so meaningfully at the time of the original McCarthy hearings.  "Good Night, and Good Luck" is something more than just a History Channel documentary about old-time events, but at the same time it is on some level done in by its own narrative, as the story by definition cannot have a happy ending or a dramatic grand finale.  Still, do not miss it.

reviewText: The United States is a great place for the creation of dreams. It's citizens are privileged to seek fame or fortune or to alter those of others. Those fragile fortunes always stride hand in hand with the fear of losing them. In the 1950's when the country was riding the high road of prosperity, Americans were enjoying the benefits of the second world war. With little to fear, it was left to the government to create one. It was called the "Red scare" or Communism. Most Americans were too complacent to worry about it. Thus it was left to one man to not only terrorize us with that fear, but to cultivate it. That individual was Joseph MaCarthy who hitched his star to a threat not of his creation, but his decision to feed, nurture and manipulate it to destroy the lives, careers and dreams of many citizens. In this remarkable film, audiences are given the rare opportunity to witness the classic confrontation between the Junior senator from Wisconsin and the controversial, chain-smoking hero of CBS, one Edward R. Murrow (superbly play by David Strathairn.) The film is in Black and white as were the issues of the day. Noted for it's caricatures of the CBS news staff, the film pointedly reveals the uncertainties, triumphs and tragedies of the times. A courageous attempt to remind modern audiences that our present dreams and fears are no less precarious. With the government adroitly using the fears of global terrorism, a man like Edward Murrow is not only welcomed, but long overdue. ****

reviewText: The CIA of the 1950's was gaining unchecked power and had recently launched "Operation Mockingbird", a project designed to gain influence over all forms of media both domestic and foreign. The project quickly became a vast success. Feeling threatened by the advance of the CIA, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the FBI, began to spy on CIA agents and their affiliates digging deep into their past. Hoover soon uncovered details linking high profile figures of state to the Communist party. Hoover passed these details onto Sen. Joseph McCarthy. Edward R. Murrow was on the direct payroll of the CIA at the time and excepted large sums of cash during the "Project Mockingbird" days. Murrow along with CBS and several newspapers were ordered to go after Joseph McCarthy by The Washington Post, when McCarthy dug too close to the CIA's domestic interests. The Washington Post held a key role in this propaganda network as it was the duty of the Post to keep an eye over the industry.  On the request of Hoover, McCarthy erroneously went after CIA agent Cord Meyer. Meyer may have held some Communist ties but was heavily protected by his friends at the CIA, which included Allen W. Dulles and Frank Wisner.Wisner, outraged by McCarthy's actions, unleashed "Mockingbird" on Sen. McCarthy. Soon the CIA was paying bribes to correspondents at: NBC, The New York Herald Tribune, CBS, and dozens of affiliates to portray McCarthy in an intensely negative light.Alfred Friendly (played by George Clooney) was a former intelligence man during World War II, who later became an IC (Independent Contractor) for the CIA while working at the Washington Post. Fred Friendly was later brought to CBS to oversee propaganda efforts there on behalf of the government. The sabotage effort cost the CIA about $350 Million a year in under the table bribes to the news papers and reporters at various media outlets. Today this practice of bribes for propaganda lives on at ABC (George Stephanopoulos CFR/Bilderburg) and CNN (Anderson Cooper CIA) as well as many newspaper and internet media outlets. George Clooney the director of this propaganda piece, is an IC for the CIA as was his character Alfred Friendly, a little inside joke to his friends at the agency.

reviewText: Politics aside (for a moment), let me get one thing out of the way right off: David Strathairn's impersonation of Edward R. Murrow is absolutely incredible -- indistinguishable in look, temperament and mannerism from actual footage of Murrow from the 1950s. Murrow comes across as dark, brooding and intense - an image not lightened by TV's harsh lighting and black-and-white spectrum. That verisimilitude carries throughout the film as well, as it captures the fashions, habits and psychological realities of the Cold War era."Good Night and Good Luck" is a political film in the best sense. Like Arthur Miller's "The Crucible," this film depicts one era in order to shed light on contemporary issues. In the 1950s, the issue was Senator Joe McCarthy's self-serving persecution of supposed communists in the American government and arts establishment. The American institutions that might have corralled McCarthy were mostly silent, cowed by the Senator's bully-boy tactics, lies and smears. The media, concerned about losing corporate sponsorship, opted for safe fare like quiz shows and Uncle Miltie. That is, until CBS newsman and TV host Edgar Murrow decided to confront McCarthy head-on.Of course, the impact of the film's political message depends on whether one sees similarities to the situation today. Director George Clooney, for one, clearly is using the film to criticize both the current government and the mainstream media. One's view of the film is bound to be colored by one's personal opinions on the matter.Murrow's 1958 speech to his CBS peers - a device that frames the film - is a challenge to use television as something more than a mere box of wires and lights. In Murrow's opinion, using a powerful medium to amuse and distract without educating and broadening is not just a wasted opportunity but a sign of America's imminent demise.The ensemble cast (incuding Clooney, Mort Downey, Jr. and Jeff Bridges) functioned impressively to give the impression of real working entity. The film's use of actual archival footage of Senator McCarthy was inspired -- having an actor play the man would have played into the charge that Clooney was exagerrating him. For all the seriousness of the film, Clooney is not above having a little fun: inserting actual commercials for Alcoa and Kent cigarettes were fun as period anchors as well as underscoring the issue of product sponsorship that continues to bedevil the media.Thankfully, Clooney lets the facts speak for themselves and does not sermonize. I found the film to be even-handed and inspiring. Murrow's brand of truth-telling does not go down smoothly, but is absolutely essential for the proper functioning of a democracy. "Good Night, And Good Luck" presents the Murrow story effectively and engagingly -- and none too soon.
summary: "We cannot defend freedom abroad by deserting it at home."

reviewText: This film just needed one more five star rating to detract from the handful of people maligning it for being boring.  One review actually seems to be complaining because it wasn't enough like Clooney's "Batman" performances.  All and all this was an incredible film about an important subject, like any Hollywood depiction of an actual time or place there were some factual inaccuracies, but "Good Night and Good Luck" can hardly be faulted because it didn't go into depth about communist activities or about other newsmen attacking McCarthy.  That being said the film is in black and white and is about politics in the 50's, if those are things that you can't get passed just don't watch it, don't take home a black and white "Documentary" styled film then spend the next week ranting online about how "I didn't like learning when I was in school and I don't like it now" (paraphrasing a real review on Amazon).  Also it is low on action so if the topic itself doesn't interest you the film won't; far and away the most animated character is found in the real life clips of Senator McCarthy carrying out his witch hunts.  It is hard not to draw parallels between McCarthyism and the current administration as many other reviewers have pointed out but the film is best watched for what it is, the retelling of one of the most important battles in American history, not the fight between Murrow and McCarthy but the struggle between our civil liberties and out desire for security.  As Ben Franklin said "The man who trades freedom for security does not deserve nor will he ever receive either."
summary: Should be required viewing right now!!!

reviewText: The best part of the film was that it was shot in glorious black and white. It was a brilliant decision and it worked. The second best part was the background jazz music. The acting and casting were outstanding. The movie evoked the era very well: the smoking, the drinking, and the language. Clooney wisely had several of Murrow's editorials read on the air in the movie. Murrow's strong prose in his editorials carried the movie.I did not give the movie five stars for little reasons. Strathairn, although he duplicated the speech patterns of Murrow, he did not evoke Murrow for me. Furthermore, there were some loose ends in the movie. People were called to talk to the CBS's lawyers, but that was all you heard about it. The movie did not evoke the fear of the communist threat very well. The movie made McCarthy out to be a complete idiot. What the movie audience might not now understand was that Communism infiltration was a palpable threat. McCarthy could not gain the power he did without a legimate threat. You could taste it back then. The majority of the threats were imagined, but a few were real. McCarthy's evil was that he went about addressing the threat in the worst way possible. If a democratic government can not stand public scrutiny of its actions or enforce the writ of habeas corpus, how good is that government? We need to balance carefully our need for security and our freedoms. McCarthy obviously crossed the line, but the movie did not explain the context of how he came into power. The movie did not evoke the cold war atmosphere that well.Again, I strongly recommend the movie. The movie tells an important story and tells it in a very entertaining manner. The movie has a good message about personal responsibility and standing up to injustice from the government.

reviewText: Clooney presents the confrontation between McCarthy, the Communist "hunter" and Murrow, a reporter and newsman that is the model of what every reporter should be and typically is not today.From the Senate hearings to his ultimate downfall, it presents McCarthy for the raving maniac that he was. The use of historical footage makes the story telling accurate and terrifying.The movie is instantly engaging. I didn't realize for nearly twenty minutes that it was in black and white. The shot of Friendly tapping Murrow's leg for his silent cue are the kind of cinematography details that makes us part of the action.Most importantly one cannot forget Murrow's words to the press association as he is receiving an award. He foretold the downfall of true and quality journalism, its decay driven by entertainment hungry public, not wanting to hear the truth, and profit hungry corporate heads not willing to hold the line on journalistic integrity.A must see, because it is real, it is based on thoughtful dialogue, and it is a warning.

reviewText: This claustrophobic, colorless film huddles you around the smoky mic of a daring and bold Radio head, ahead of his times. The stark white brillance of the lights cast bold shadows that raise the tension with the piercing black, and the real life, archive footage give you the sense of history unraveling before your eyes. This authentic, and passionate film by george clooney made me believe there is more to Clooney than Clooney. A happy addition to a wave of new 'thought' provoking directors.

reviewText: This is one of the best political movies that depicts the mood of the nation durring the prime of the Cold War.  A time when rightly choosing to join any organization associated with the communist party, either in the present of the 1950s or twenty years in the past when the US and USSR were stuanch allies, was a treasonous offense condemned by McCarthy's regime of the House of Un-American Activities Committee without trial and without evidence.  This movie does a very good job in how the  politicians of tyranny exploit the fear that the average American may sometimes exhibit.  Good Night and Good Luck goes further to expose the slavery of censorship that the United States government, broadcasting corporations, and simple reporters are many times subject to.Not only that, but the directing is phenomenal.  Never thought Clooney had it in him.  The most important scenes are highlighted by an intense errie silence at times.  The black and white filming is simply classic.  And the old cigarette commercials are simply hilarious.  Simply put, this film is smart, historically accurate, and breath-takingly hypnotic.

reviewText: How refreshing to watch a thought-provoking, intelligent film for a change.  Takes you away from the microwave, tweeting, violent culture we now live in and dumps you deep into yesterday's world of betrayal and intrigue.  I actually believe this should be required viewing for America's youth so they would more carefully consider social, political and moral decisions.  The right-leaning "group think" of the 1950's as portrayed in GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK, still exists today but it exists on the left, as it is no longer possible to disagree with current, left-leaning societal tendencies without suffering brutal character assasination. This new millennium "McCarthyism" is allowed to thrive simply because we have failed to educate our youth.  GOOD NIGHT AND GOOD LUCK is informative, thoughtful and entertaining enough, to help provide the education our nation's youth so badly need.  A great movie.  It made it to my "Top 10 Movies of All Time List."

reviewText: It is impossible to describe how incredibly moving and profound this film is.  You just have to see it.  David Strathairn gives one of the most riveting performances I have ever seen.  He certainly deserves the Oscar for this.This film is great in every way --the performances, cinematography, story, dialogue, and sets.  However, I think the most important thing about this film is the unfolding of the drama between the dangerous senator McCarthy and Edward R. Murrow.  The parallels between the McCarthy era and today are more than frightening.  Unless the America of today can come up with people with the courage and conviction to stand up to budding fascism like Edward R. Murrow did we are all in deep trouble.George Clooney has proved himself to be an excellent writer/director.One of the best films ever made.

reviewText: I enjoyed this movie more on an artistic level than as a history lesson.  One of the problems faced when a movie is made concerning recent events and characters is that the public can still remember the originals.  This was very skillfully addressed in this movie by interlacing the actors with historical footage that made sense--as opposed to trying to electronically weave them together.This movie is too confined to be considered a history lesson in the period of McCarthy/Kefauver paranoia.  However, it is probably wise in narrowing the scope of coverage.  It would not be possible to encompass all this area meant, including the shocking lack of leadership by President Eisenhower in denouncing the hysteria until it was winding down.I wish I'd purchased the 2-DVD set simply to see the production details.  I am curious regarding which scenes were shot on a location vs. created sets.  Geography was limited to what appears to be a couple of buildings.Black-and-white movies, like black-and-white photos, have a certain artistry because they can only speak in a limited vocabulary.  Unlike the old classic b/w films of the last century, its use here is intentional and sometimes obtrusive.  What with the constant smoking and the haze floating through so many scenes one wonders how people found their way around!  It was fun to watch, but overdone.  Unlike the best b/w films of the distant past, this movie doesn't let you forget its technique; it wants you to notice it.  I was alive then and it never was that dark!All the actors were good, the filming was sufficiently gray and dark that it took a while to recognize Mr. Clooney.  I suppose Frank Langella did a decent portrayal of Mr. Paley, but perhaps I've read too much on Mr. Paley to buy into it.  Ed Murrow was a womanizer and party animal, but we certainly saw none of that in this movie.I purchased this movie and saw it within a couple of days of buying and watching "Walk the Line".  That was a better movie, though I wanted to like this one more for its subject and content.

reviewText: The movie is shot in black & white, verite style which may scare off some. It is 1953, & the little demagogue, Sen. Joe McCarthy is terrorizing the nation with his hearings. There is a communist under every bed & it doesn't matter how many lives & careers he ruins. David Strathan plays Edward Murrow to perfection. He has his look, his speech patterns & mannerism down pat. George Clooney produced & directed this movie & plays Fred Friendly, chief of CBS news. They decide to take on McCarthy & his lies via television news. The McCarthy hearings were also on t.v. Frank Langella plays the part of William Paley, CEO of CBS, superbly. He feels the pressure of Murrow's broadcasts & the fear of sponsors deserting CBS. He wavers but ultimately does the right thing & supports Murrow. In Senator McCarthy's mind either you were with him or a communist. He accuses Murrow of being a red which was a lie. But by that time "tail gunner Joe" was finished. Murrow's broadcasts were merely the final push. This movie is not your typical entertainment per se but it is gripping, serious. drama. If I say the word history, many will scurry away. McCarthy was one of the biggest threats our republic has had in its history. McCarthy was an egotisical, ignorant Senator with a drinking problem. We were all so lucky that he was as self destructive as he was.The theater, at the metro-plex, last weekend, was over half full. Interestingly, I saw not one face of a person under 30. I guess they were all down the hall watching Harry Potter or Chicken Little. This is a great movie for history teachers & their classes once it becomes a dvd. An important subject covered well. Definitely five stars.
summary: McCarthy is  a  stain & an embarassment to  the U.S.

reviewText: It's clear that this movie was a work of art but also a work of love.George Clooney, who has been himself accused of "pinko" sentiments, has outdone himself in directing and producing a first-rate piece here.  It is disheartening that he chooses to finish this otherwise inspirational story with a reflection that, even in 1954, broadcast journalism was not "what it used to be," and that cynics will ultimately be proven correct.You see, the movie also makes us reflect (almost unconsciously) about how many things are better now that they were fifty years ago...1.  Nowhere near as many people smoke as did then - and Murrow himself died of lung cancer.2.  The internet has become our great democratizer.  Paley's character is an autocrat - someone who OWNS the media and who thus decides what people will and won't see.  Today the relative power of centralized media - TV and newspapers - might be concentrated in fewer hands, but it is ever so much more balanced through blogs, listservs and other democratizing forces.3.  Anybody can produce a documentary.  There's one circulating now about 9/11, for example.  I'd guess that millions of people have seen it, and yet it's never been shown or hinted at in the "mass media."4.  Stereotyping has given way to highly desirable "political correctness," and thank goodness.  There's more mutual respect in our current culture than before, and less institutionalized racism.One thing is for sure:  after seeing this movie, you gain an admiration for the heroism of journalists doing "their job," even if it means taking an editorial stand.  But I also had little craving to go back to 1954.We're much better off now...believe it, or not.  Murrow's good luck must have stuck...

reviewText: Good night and good luckA very good film. For those who remember the McCarthy days, and more importantly for those who do not, this is a must-see. It presents in a very short hour and a half a very compelling picture of a very dark time in the history of the U.S. I won't bore you with a long diatribe, so suffice it to say that Murrow (and Fred Friendly, et. al) was a beacon of sanity and reason at a time when paranoid delusions were becoming the national religion. (Any resemblance to the world today is purely coincidental............Yeah, right. Didn't Santayana remind us about those who fail to remember the past.....?)The film is not preachy or pushy, it lets the quiet determination of Murrow speak for itself. His name should be far better known than it is, and this film will help remedy that sorry situation. This is one of those films that remind us that it is not just soldiers who fight to defend our ideal of democracy - it is up to all of us to uphold that ideal in our everyday life. (And that is seldom easy.)Apart from the content, I also enjoyed the way the film was done. I grew up on black and white TV, and this film captures the feel of that, at least to some degree. The more I see of George Clooney's work, the more impressed I am. David Strathairn also did a remarkable job as Murrow. The stark shots, high contrast, and so on, were very effective, IMHO,  and the jazz breaks were great (including a nice, mellow cover of one of my favorite Les Paul and Mary Ford tunes, How High The Moon).The featurette on the making of the film was also very welcome. I like to have a "behind the scenes" view of the production, but with a film like this it becomes almost a necessity. The historical importance of the content alone merits that. It is billed as a docudrama, meaning that it is about historical incidents, but some of it is treated with a certain creative license, although not as much as usual in a Hollywood feature film. They made a point of trying very hard to stay factual. I intend to watch it again with the audio commentary turned on. That should also be interesting.If you are up for looking at, or thinking about, a very difficult period in our history, or if you are interested in seeing a small time capsule from the 50s (amazing how much people smoked),  or are interested in the role of media in democracy, I highly recommend you at least rent this, if not buy it, and support good film.

reviewText: This is a fascinating and educational film, but viewers looking for an ordinary movie-going experience might be disappointed.  The movie is a docudrama - it is just a re-enactment of the backstage drama that went on when Edward R. Murrow, Fred Friedly, and the people at CBS News took on Senator McCarthy.  There are some references made to the personal lives of these people (there is a sub-plot about a secret marriage) but not much.  We do not follow Murrow home and Joe McCarthy appears in newsreel footage as himself.  Still, it is an intriguing look inside the world of TV journalism and of a time when television was a much simpler thing - no special effects, and Murrow reads from a script.  Of course, the obvious message is to see how our war on terror is driving us again into a state of McCarthyism, but - since none of this movie happens in the present - that remains subtext and the movie does not become overly preachy.

reviewText: I have a feeling for most people this is the kind of movie that you've either already seen or aren't interested in. But I'll go ahead and sing its praises anyway.For fellow history buffs, this is a real treat. It mixes in Hollywood stars with lots of old archival footage to give a film that feels like a gripping drama and a documentary at the same time. Although websites like wikipedia draw attention to some of the accuracy gaps in the film, I still felt like I learend a lot.And, although I'm far from the first person to mention this, its subject material couldn't have come at a more appropriate time. As you listen to discussions of civil liberties, secret military tribunals, the act of habeas corpus, and the rights of the accused to fair trial, you can't help but compare it to recent events.If you haven't seen this movie yet, I can't recommend it enough.

reviewText: This film beautifully depicts the atmosphere of the 50's--from the stark black and white photography to the smoke which constantly swirls around the head and shoulders of CBS newsman, Edward R. Murrow.  He and his producer, Fred Friendly, played by George Clooney, take on a formidable foe when they attempt to uncover the unfair tactics used by Joseph McCarthy, the "junior Senator from Wisconsin", as Murrow calls him.  Looking back, people now say that the McCarthy Senate hearings were a "witch hunt" against anyone who had ever been allied with the Communist Party in any way.  At the time, the Senator struck fear and trembling into the hearts of many Hollywood movie actors, as well as everyday citizens who were called to defend themselves against the Senate Un-American Activities Committee.  Murrow and Friendly proceed with their journalistic truth-finding campaign, despite serious opposition from critics, viewers, and some higher-ups in CBS.  William Paley, network head, supports them as long as he can, but eventually capitulates from pressure put on him by sponsors and other foes of Murrow.  This is an interesting and important movie which perhaps could have been made clearer with a written statement at the end to tell what eventually happened to McCarthy and Murrow.

reviewText: MOVIE: George Clooney's sophmore directoral attempt is not a bad one, but is it really that much of a great one? The film is a decent one, it tackles the whole event of senator Joe McCarthy's attack at communism. He basically turned and attacked everyone who opposed him and accused them of being communists.  Edward R. Murrow of CBS was the first person to attempt to oppose McCarthy. The film is basically an inside look at broadcast journalism in the 1950's.  This is where the film limits itself, and the result is that the film turns out to be very slow despite only being a little over than 90 minutes in running time.  I actually found myself admiring the interior design of the theater at Bethesda Row, because some scenes were just too boring.  The movie takes place entirely in the news studio, and is just the series of broadcasts that Murrow put on the air.  To put it simple, the film is something that the history channel might do.  You have zero character development, it's all happening in the moment, and it just never connects with the audience.  Sure there is witty dialogue now and then, but it really can't add anything to make the film interesting.  The b&w; style doesn't help either, I mean the plot is very basic and you have no depth in the characters and you go and shoot the film in black and white.  So, now the characters can't drive the plot and you can't make the film visually stimulating.  The film does hit hard with topics in broadcast journalism, and does relate to our media today.  It also suggest that the media is biased, which it is.  You'll get a different view watching FOX news versus NBC news.  The film only stands out with the actingACTING: David Strathairn steals the show as Murrow.  He is the focal point of the movie, and he does a great job with the character.  The film relys alot on facial expression, and a lot on the eyes of the actors.  There is a sense of anxiety and tension right before they go on the air with the famous report that exposed McCarthy.  The rest of the cast however is not that memorable, not even George could save his own film.  Strathairn will be nominated for this role come Golden Globes and Oscar, but this is not an award winning performance and he will not win.BOTTOM LINE: The film is a historical fluff piece that is pretty much a "what you see is what you get".  There is no depth to the film, nothing interesting for the audience to dig their teeth into.  You pretty much sit back and it's hand fed to you.  The film boasts a good leading performance, and nothing else.  They could have benefited from a musical score I can tell you that, you have no idea what a difference it would have made.
summary: Great Acting, But The Script Is A Little Dry

reviewText: This is arguably a very timely movie, considering the events of the last few years. Hopefully, those who see this movie will see how easily attempts to make the world safer can be distorted and turned into witch hunts which target even the innocent, forcing friends to betray each other in an attempt to save themselves and  making the truth hard to decipher.What is fact? What is lie? How far will McCarthy go and what is his actual agenda? Does he care if the people he targets are truly guilty? These are questions at the heart of this movie.To Clooney's credit, he doesn't hammer home any parallels to the events in the movie and current day happenings. He allows viewers to make their own comparisons - or to interpret the movie as they will.Taken simply as a recap of a very critical moment in U.S. history, this movie stands on its own, allowing the very talented (but often underated) actor, David Straithairn, to shine in one of the best roles of his career, taking on none other than Joseph McCarthy. Straithairn's performance is worthy of an Academy nomination, as is this entire film.McCarthy, of course, had few limits on who he'd go after in his attempts to root out "communists" and was singlehandedly responsible for getting many talented people blacklisted, even if they were innocent of any wrongdoing.The film is shot in black and white, which lends a very believable historical tone to the movie. Because the hearings WERE shot in black and white, it echoes the reality of the time and doesn't come across as a gimmick.Clooney took care not to water down the details of history and to be as accurate as possible in recreating the actual events portrayed here. He has admitted that it was a labor of love and partially made as an homage to his father,( Nick Clooney)who was a radio journalist and often spoke to his son of the McCarthy trials. Luckily, the son paid attention to his father's message and took care to portray both Edward R. Murrow and Joseph MsCarthy with painstaking accuracy.
summary: Not only timely but an amazingly accurate recreation of a critical event
