reviewText: Here is the skinny on this movie:A black and white movie about the interesection of politics and journalism, and the freedom of the press to serve its twin masters of 'the public interest' and business needs.Edmund Murrow, as portrayed by David Straitharn is so immersed in charecter, I forgot this is the guy is so many of 'those' movies.  Was this really Meryl Streep's estranged husband in "The River Wild'?  Director George Clooney shows great promise behind and in front of the camera.  Clooney portrays producer Fred Friendly to Straitharn's Edmund Murrow.  Others you have seen before play other actual charecters from the 'McCarthy' era, including Robert Downey and Frank Langella.  It is a very good cast in what is mostly ensemble acting.  Don't expect deep portrayls of each charecter, it doesn't exist here.Essentially, this movie is about the confrontation of Murrow and Friendly and McCarthy, and how Murrow felt that McCarthy's tactics need to be exposed.  However, you don't really need to know anything about McCarthy or Murrow to understand and enjoy this movie.  Great acting and a great story provide intellectual excitement.  The fircrackers are really about the debate itself rather than what you see onscreen.  There isn't screaming and yelling to abound - but rather confrontations about ideas.Clooney filmed this movie in black and white - which is a nice move because it allows the use of actual footage from hearings, it gives a crisp noirish feel to the movie, and somehow it evokes the era, and gives added depth to the actors faces.Essentially, the story is a study in the human drama unfolding between a crusading journalist, the owner of CBS - William Paley, and the interests each thinks it serves.  The speech which bookends the movie seems timely, because in many ways the premise of the film is that television - according to Murrow - should serve a higher purpose, and yet the realities of business always nip at the public interest's heels.I find that the movie doesn't really speak to the current time as much as many wish it did - the reality is that the movie could have aired in any number of decades of American history and still be relevant.  The fact is that the movie is about the reality of journalism and economics.  Such is the tension of a free press.Thus, anyone expecting to see a damnation of the current administration in thinly veiled history is deluding themselves - it really doesn't apply here as it could to any other administration.  The tension between being able to speak truth to power is always with us, fortunately, and of course filled with great tension.A 'small' movie about an important premise, part civics lesson, and definitely entertaining, it is a movie worth seeing.  Leave political beliefs at the theatre door and become immersed in a battle that should always be waged in a vigorous democracy.

reviewText: Good Night, and Good Luck was the famous television sign-off by one of American television's most famous journalists; Edward R. Morrow of CBS.  Jumping into the national spotlight with his work during WWII, Morrow became a mainstay of American TV during the 1950s.  This show expands on one of the most important chapters of his career, his initial and public questioning of Senator McCarthy's tactics on his news show.  This questioning would be the beginning of the end for McCarthy, as it led others to oppose the red-baiting senator, and eventually to his censure by the US Senate.The entire movie is shown in black and white to parallel television of that time.  The primary setting is the studios and offices of CBS, and occasionally the homes and restaurants frequented by the employees of CBS at that time.  George Clooney is not the star of this movie, but certainly deserved the Supporting Actor Academy Award nomination.  No, the star is David Straithairn, who plays Edward R. Morrow.  The face and voice are spot on.  Outside of the central confrontation between McCarthy and Morrow, the movie subtly highlights many other features of life in the 1950s.  One for example is the marriage between two of the CBS employees.  Many US corporations at that time banned employees from marrying each other, but if you were high enough in the chain of command, you could probably get by with a wink of the eye and purposeful ignorance of your co-workers.  Another example is the prevalence of smoking in the workplace, something that essentially disappeared in corporate America by the 1980s.The movie and its central conflict are bookended by a speech Morrow gives at an awards function in which he attacks the transformation of television from a medium of inspiration and education to a medium of entertainment.  All in all, a great movie.  It comes in at 1.5 hours, and so flows quite quickly.  It is worth watching.
summary: Would you rather be yellow or red?

reviewText: ... and in the land of the blind, i.e. Amerika in the 21st Century, who is king?In the early 1950's, Amerika, the poster nation for paranoid schizophrenia, set about ridding itself of communists. Ther had been political precedents for the action: England starving the Gaelic Irish in the middle of the 19th Century, Nazi Germany ethnically cleansing its Aryan race in the 30's and 40's, still there was room to refine the tactic. Enter a neo-con from the great state of Minnesota, dabble in draconian fear mongering with the homo-erotic fanatacism of an FBI director whose tastes were kept secret and would today be the envy of Michael Jackson, target a group who simplistically embraced a totalitarian principle out of intellectual naivete (almost as pernicious a disease as fanatical obedience), and you begin to ride the slippery slope toward an Orwellian nightmare. Lives were ruined, careers dashed, suicides ensued in order to keep the red threat at bay. Of course, today, the Red Threat has more to do with a neo-christian fascism with a particular red state and texas twang.It's no accident that George Clooney had the courage to make and then release this film. It should have been awarded Best Picture, but, you see, Hollywood still hasn't recovered from the first purge, and what there is there in the likes of Spielberg, Lucas and so many others is a buy into the whole capitalist machine. They dislike what the neo-cons stand for, but not that much. At least not until they are ordered back into the boxcars.This is the engaging story of a man who essentially was an ardent patriot and had little intellectual sympathy for the naivete mentioned above. At the same time, he had not lost his moral compass and knew right from wrong, good from evil. Steeling his nerve he dared take on the black knight of American paranoia and his own boss, another one whose ethnic background should have taught him the dangers inherent in molly-coddling with a capitalist hegemony that would grind him and his tribe under the wheel, and were in fact in the process of doing so, but Paley is another story.David Straitharn and George Clloney and the entire cast give performances for the ages. Every word rings true. The portrait of Murrow here is a portrait in courage that few have ever embraced. Like those kids in front of the Chinese tanks in Tianemin Square, Murrow stood up to a fascist machine and refused to capitulate for the sake of his own safety.Are there any such men today? Joe Wilson, perhaps. Not many more. Cindy Sheehan, the Zappala family, a handful of others. Why?In the 19th Century, German philosopher Georg Wilhelm Hegel lamented that his fellow German countrymen were all to willing to surrender their freedoms in return for a pittance in tax relief.Has anything changed? Why doesn't this outrage you?

reviewText: This film deals with 1950's journalism and politics. It depicts the CBS News investigation of Senator Joseph McCarthy. Done by CBS television's "See It Now" unit, the program sought to show how Senator McCarthy was misusing his investigative power.Senator McCarthy claimed he was trying to find Communists within the government. So far as is known, he didn't find any Communists but he gained a lot of public attention for his investigations.The film - done from an inside perspective at CBS News - is a period piece, but rather an interesting one. It shows how much sweat and toil went into producing the story on McCarthy and its aftermath.Edward R. Murrow and "See it Now" produced what has come to be recognized as a historic documentary. Told in flashback from 1958, when Murrow gave a speech critical of the broadcast industry, this is a film well worth seeing.

reviewerName: Paul Tognetti "The real world is so much more...
reviewText: He really was broadcast journalism's first superstar.  Edward R. Murrow was not a particularly handsome man nor did he possess the charisma that seems to be a prerequisite to be a television anchor in our day.  Rather,  Murrow was  a dedicated journalist who cared deeply about his country and who would ultimately risk his career in the pursuit of a story.  "Good Night, and Good Luck" is George Clooney's outstanding 2005 film recalling Murrow's relentless investigation into the motivation behind and the conduct of the House Un-American Activities Committee (or HUAC) hearings of the early 1950s led by Wisconsin's Republican Senator Joseph McCarthy.  It was McCarthy and the Committee's chief counsel Roy Cohn who sought to prove their claim that hundreds of avowed Communists were working covertly as Soviet spies in the U.S. government.  Filmed in black and white and sprinkled with actual footage of these historic hearings "Good Night, and Good Luck" recalls those days marked by fear and paramoia and proves once again that sometimes the best strategy is to let people keep talking and allow them to discredit themselves.  It is a compelling story!"Good Night, and Good Luck" features a fine ensemble cast led by David Strathaim who shines in the role of Ed Murrow and Clooney himself who plays Murrow's producer Fred Friendly.  Other notable performances include Robert Downey Jr. in the role of CBS News correspondent Joseph Wershba and Frank Langella who portrays the conflicted chief executive of CBS William Paley.  Clearly, Ed Murrow and CBS News stuck their neck out in an effort to expose the draconian tactics being employed by Senator McCarthy and his followers.  One wishes that news organizations these days had the guts to do the same.  Clooney chose to punctuate his film with a number of clips featuring jazz singer Dianne Reeves.  I thought this tactic was extremely effective in giving the audience a sense of just what was going on in America back in the early 1950's."Good Night, and Good Luck" reminds us what the goals of an individual reporter and a news organization really should be. Broadcast journalists should report the news not comment on it.  Meanwhile, if a network feels compelled to editorialize that is fine but the commentary should be clearly labelled as such.  It is sad to see what network and cable news programs have become.  Seeing "Good Night, and Good Luck" reminded me of the outstanding network news organizations at both CBS and NBC when I was growing up.  I hope that I live to see the day when that kind of quality reporting is once again the rule rather than the exception.  "Good Night, and Good Luck" is one of the best new films I have seen in a very long time.  Very highly recommended
summary: A look back at the work of one of the pioneers of broadcast journalism.

reviewText: Although ostensibly about the famous newsman Edward R. Murrow, this is really an opportunity for Director/Actor/Co-Writer Clooney to remind the American people to be vigilant about members of their own government trying to manipulate them to their own ends.In this case the culprit is Senator Joe McCarthy who Murrow took on in the 1950's.Clooney set himself some tough limitations in this film constraining himself to shooting on a few indoor sets. It could easily be produced as a play.The actors in the film are quite deadpan, especially Murrow himself, leaving the viewer oddly unmoved. The most compelling aspects of the film are the archival footage of McCarthy, Eisenhower, the HUAC and Senate hearings, and the fine words of Murrow himself.This film will appeal to film students and people interested in this dark era in American history. The commentary by Clooney and Grant Heslov is excellent.
summary: Entertaining if oddly unmoving film about a dark era in American History

reviewText: I was midway through the elementary grades when Murrow confronted McCarthy.  It was fun to see a glimpse of real life in the '50's again other than stuff like "Happy Days."  The only possible slight anachronism was a nice ballpoint pen used by one of the characters.  A fountain pen would have been more likely for the time, although a ballpoint would have been possible.  The actor who plays Ed Murrow is very, very good.  You think it is Murrow even if you are very familiar with Murrow's face, voice, and mannerisms.  The film shows the conflicts and risks early TV journalists experienced to confront an evil at which many others cowered.  Yet, it does so without the media wrapping itself in the flag as if it could do no wrong.  The extra features on the DVD are well worth viewing, even if they run nearly as long as the actual film!  The use of period film clips blends seamlessly into the film.  The fact the film is done in black and white only enhances the story, especially for those of us who well remember black and white TV broadcasts as "normal."
summary: Tells the story without an agenda

reviewText: Good Night and Good Luck: Reviewed by Philip HenryI am fortunate to be old enough to remember watching the Army-McCarthy Hearings on television. I recall Boston Attorney Joseph Welch,  after having his client subjected to McCarthy's sleazy innuendo, demanding: "Sir, Have you no Decency?"We are all fortunate that CBS, then America's preeminent network, had journalists of the caliber of Edward R. Murrow and Fred Friendly to call McCarthy on the tactics in a courageous series of broadcasts.It wasn't too long after the Hollywood 10 Witchhunt that ended or clouded the career of a dozen writers and directors. It took creative energy from Arthur Miller (The Crucible) and others to point to the parallels between the Salem Witch Trials and the McCarthy Era.  It's difficult today to remember the fear and paranoia that McCarthy engendered, but watching George Clooney's "Good Night and Good Luck" brings it all back. The Question "Are you now, or have you ever been, a Member of the Communist Party" was everywhere.When a young Lieutenant was drummed out of the Air Force as a Security Risk because his father was a European Immigrant with tenuous connections to socialism, Murrow and Friendly acted.  Working with strict professionalism and understatement,they excoriated McCarthy and portrayed him as the  sputtering, devious political hack that he was.The casting is superb, with David Strathairn  as Murrow, Clooney as Friendly, Robert Downey Jr. and Frank Langella as CBS Chairman William Paley.The editing is remarkable, intercutting 1950's footage of McCarthy as himself with contemporary interviews.  The mood and feel of the film is great: black and white cinematography; starched white shirts, gray flannel suits and the ever-present cigarette for the men; and wonderful music.In the defining moment of the film(the live broadcast in which Murrow directly takes on McCarthy)the tension is palpable.  The Control Room was a scene of controlled chaos with producers, directors and technicians scrambling to get the show on the air. Paley comes into the control room in a show of support, despite the danger to his Network.As Murrow says during the show's preparation,"The Fear is in this room."*****  An intense and remarkably well done testament to the courage of three men.Too bad that it couldn't be done today: too many squeamish Corporate "suits" with no understanding of Journalism control the Media.

reviewText: I appreciated this informative and entertaining film.  It's important to remember the ways in which authoritarian elements of our society attempt to intimidate people who question the orthodoxy of Big Business.  Figures like Sean Hannity now play the role of high priest, hunting down any figure who may in some way threaten the holy crusade of profit maximization, and the propaganda required to pull it off.  This country could use the sort of labor-based party that we find in most of the world, as well as more civic groups that question corporatism, militarism, and the divine right of capital.The paranoid dominator spirit of McCarthy lives on in some of us, but there is a growing segment of the population that has grown tired of the thought control and are finding alternative views of our society in thoughtful films like this, radio programs like "Democracy Now!," journals like "The International Socialist Review," and books like "Wobblies!"  They all advocate subversive ideas like global solidarity.There's a scene in "Good Night, and Good Luck" where people are being interrogated for their alleged involvement in a union called the International Workers of the World.  It motivated me to google this organization, and now I'm a member.For additional films that challenge Big Business and its servants, I'd recommend "The Corporation" and "Bread and Roses."
Title: N/A

reviewText: The sad part about this movie is that it is a self-fulfilling prophecy in and of itself.  The movie is bookended by a speech by Murrow about the potential that television can have for the enlightenment of humanity.  In the speech, Murrow correctly predicted that television would instead appeal to the lowest common denominator.  Thus, instead of education, we got stupidity.  Instead of "See It Now" we got "Temptation Island."  Thus, a movie about serious issues has the unfortunate fate of having a short run in the major metropolitan areas, and having an even shorter one in the secondary markets.  The real crux of the movie is about the Red Scare of the 1950's and how Murrow and McCarthy faced off.  Murrow of course won and McCarthy was defeated.  The screenwriter would have us believe that Murrow and CBS single-handedly brought down McCarthyism.  The truth of the matter is that McCarthy had not only reached the point of self-destruction, he had also reached the tipping point of angering friends and associates in higher places.  I give credit to Clooney for giving us the extended footage of Welch's rebuke of McCarthy ending in "Have you no sense of decency sir, at long last?"  Although directed by well entrenched Hollywood figure George Clooney, the movie has been basically ignored by mainstream media, and as said before, has had a very short run in the secondary markets.In a time when opposition to war is spun as unpatriotic, it is refreshing to hear that we should not confuse dissent with disloyalty.  When we live in a culture of media scare tactics, we should hear: "we will not walk in fear of one another."  "Good Night, and Good Luck" besides being beautifully filmed, should be shown to the younger generation who have no idea who Joe McCarthy is, besides a fleeting reference to McCarthyism in their High School reading of "The Crucible."  Although the movie focuses on the downfall of McCarthy, the real horror story is how fast the contagion of McCarthyism spread through the country.  In the end, this film is really about bravery and practicing what you preach.  But, did Murrow win?  Yes, he and others besides him beat back McCarthy, but the war for television, I believe, was lost the moment television executives realized that TV is so good at its worst, why even try for its best.  In that way, Murrow may have indeed won the battle, but lost the war.(I would encourage anyone to read Murrow's speech at [...])
summary: This just might do nobody any good.

reviewText: While I thoroughly enjoy George Clooney as an actor, I submit that his real talent (and love) is directing.  After seeing his directorial debut "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind" which followed the exploits of Chuck Barry, there is no denying that George has a way around the camera.Here he shoots in crisp black and white and the superimposition of the real Senator Joe McCarthy is most effective and certainly complements the mood and feel he so successfully captured.Another wooooooooooooooonderful bonus is the incomparable Dianne Reeves who provided sparkling vocals to the movie soundtrack.This is a very good look at a shameful period in American history and without hammering you over the head with it, gives a candid view of what countless reporters during the time had to deal with as well as the many, many lives destroyed because of this ludicrous excuse for a Senator.Excellent movie.

Title: N/A

reviewText: A personal friend and mentor always says "the truth will withstand the brightest light."  Senator Joseph McCarthy demonstrated one of the greatest abuses of political power based upon the social fear of communism following WWII.  For over four years beginning in early 1950 he trampled upon the US Constitution with his allegations of communist infiltrations in the government and society.  In 1953, in conjunction with McCarthy's ill-fated investigation of an alledged spy ring in the the US Army, Edward R. Murrow's program about the unsubstantiated dismissal of a loyal USAF officer played a pivotal role turning the tide of public opinion against a seemingly invincible government official. Murrow's program helped focus the brightest of lights on McCarthy under which his paranoia-fed falsehoods eventualy wilted.  "Good Night, and Good Luck" details the backstory of Murrow's effort.The movie was filmed in color and digitized later to B&W.;  B&W; movies have a way of intensifying the drama of a scene when the lighting and shadows are perfect.  Although there are many brilliant B&W; scenes in the film there are also several scenes that appear flat, muting the drama.  That is my only criticism of the film.  Overall though the B&W; is effectual, adding a period anchor to the early 50's when all TV was B&W.;Every actor in the cast rose to a level of their art that is impressive so it would be foolish to list them all here.  I will say David Strathairn's performance of Murrow truly deserved the Best Actor Oscar nomination he received.Finally, the quality of the DVD transfer.  I picked up a used copy of the movie here on Amazon for 1 cent plus shipping, a price that's tough to beat.  The images on the DVD played on an HD system with DVD enhancing technology rate "almost blu-ray perfect" on my subjective scale and the Dolby 5.1 sound is very satisfying.It you enjoy films of political history, get "Good Night, and Good Luck."
summary: The Truth will always withstand the brightest light - a great film

reviewText: The nominations and awards are out now, and "Good Night, and Good Luck" seems to be the Indie darling. It about a period of American history that is so embarrassing and, yet, so fascinating. A documentary from the 60's, "Point of Order", was all about the Army vs McCarthy hearings. This film is compelling from beginning to end. George Clooney definitely had an idea, and ran with it. His best choice was David Strathairn as Edward R. Murrow. He was certainly an excellent choice, and is excellent with everything the script asked him to do. Unfortunatey, aside from his blatant integrity, we end up knowing nothing about Murrow, as the man. Apparently, he's a family man, but no mention of the family seems to be important. Then, there's a big deal made about Robert Downey, Jr., and Patricia Clarkson being married. I wasn't sure why that was important, other than to suggest that married peope couldn't work at the station; also, they were the best at their jobs. Another thing that bothered me was that Mr.Clooney seemed to expect the general audience to already have some background before they come in. I had this background, but wonder if those going without this knowledge would understand how brutal and devastating this actually was. McCarthy was an egomaniac, and it's impossible to understand where he was coming from. Clooney handled this the only way possible, by using actual footage. Roy Cohn, "Angels in America" aside, was also shown for his true colors. David Strathairn gives a totally complete performance, given his script limitations. He gives Murrow the dignity and strength of purpose that were so much his trademark. If supporting kudos should go out, they should go to Frank Langella as Paley, the real reason Murrow was allowed to continue his assault on McCarthy. As I said, once McCarthy was unglued, Murrow's family faced lots of potential turmoil as a result. Regardless, Clooney opened the gates to see a slice of American life, shameful as it was, in the glorious black & white glory that we all experienced back when. This is a fine achievement, and worthy of your consideration.  UPDATE: I tried to discuss this film with my young co-workers, and they didn't know anything abot it, nor did they care.. Go figure...

reviewerName: Richard W Little "I am a maple leaf on the wi...
reviewText: A few weeks ago we went to see Good Night, and Good Luck. It's the story of the collision between the legendary newsman Edward R. Murrow and the head of the 1950s Communist witch-hunt, Senator Joseph McCarthy. Murrow used his television news program to attack the abuses of government during that time frame, using facts as the best weapon in his arsenal.The film shows the times and issues as complex. Folks have to watch what they say, are nervous about vague associations they may have had 20 years previously, and have to hide relationships they should be proud of. It's an understated portait of the times, never simplifying the issues at hand, and always "showing" rather than "telling".And the parallels to today are a little concerning.This is a George Clooney directed film, and he does a good job with a diverse, talented cast. David Strathairn, as Murrow, performs outstandingly. The film is shot in black and white, conveying that sense of times-gone-past.A definite recommendation, for those who want to see a movie that will make them think.

reviewText: There's a lot to admire in Clooney's,'Goodnight & Good Luck', primarily for me in its resonance for the current, divisive Bush administration. But its snappy and good to look at, powering with the speed of news itself through its 90 minutes. Munrow stands statuesque in face of the screen images of McCarthy's self-righteous claims against people of alledged communist persuasion. Without knowledge of Munrow I can't assess the accuracy of this portrayal, but it works in the film. The stoic crusader gets a nuanced treatment by the superb acting of Strathain. The 50s are equally evinced; the baggy duds,the lunatic advertising, the offices, a smog of cigarettes, the infant medium's techniques, by our current standards, crazily over-staffed. The film's black and white, rather like the Cohen's,'Man Who Wasn't There', helps not only the mood of the 50s, but more easily facilitates coherent dialogue with archival footage of court proceedings. If you're hungering for a complete bite into the life of Murrow or McCarthy you've come to the wrong place. The intention of the film is surely to pluck appropriate material for our times, and in this Clooney is right on target. To defy corporate and sponsorship pressures and examine the lies and scaremongering tactics of the powers that be is brave stuff, and I applaud Clooney and the producers for going at those mighty jugulars.

reviewText: This is one of the best movies I've seen in years.  Perhaps the drama of the piece is lost on some because we know what happened.  I found the whole movie riveting(when I first got it, I watched it twice in a row without a break).  It's good to know that there are still films being made that can hold attention in that manner.As for the politics of the film, we still have defenders of both McCarthy and Murrow.  And both sides have good points to make.  Perhaps they are both correct in that we should always be on the guard against people in government who will subvert this country for a foreign power (but keep in mind that it's not just commies who are/were trying to subvert our government), and that those who are doing so should do so within our framework of laws (I think the past several years of the current administration should have taught us this lesson again).All-in-all, an excellent film!

reviewText: George Clooney has come into his own as a writer and director. His attention to detail and realism, rivals almost anything else I've seen out there in years. It's almost too much like watching a documentary. A bit talky for its 93 minutes, but should be seen by Americans as a reminder of modern-day witch hunts, and how the lives of innocent people are sucked-in and destroyed. The real star of this film however, is David Strathairn's effective portrayal of Edward R. Murrow. One of the better biographical characterizations by any actor. This is not a film I'll be watching over-and-over again though.

reviewText: This very well written, well directed and beautifully filmed movie attempts to perpetuate the myths of the McCarthy era while ostensively telling the story of Edward R Murrow. For the knowledgeable viewer however, no case is really made against McCarthy. The rating submitted is for the technical aspects of the movie.Certainly, George Clooney, as writer and director could not make the case honestly. Surely with all the (supposedly) thousands of victims we are told about is it really necessary to work the bogus cases discussed below into the screenplay?Milo Radulovich, discharged from the Air Force, is presented at length as a victim of McCarthy, but of course, McCarthy had nothing to do with his case. This was a security issue that was handled by the Air Force itself.Annie Lee Moss is presented as a victim of McCarthy in her appearance before the committee. Ms Moss was being questioned as a witness in trying to determine who had promoted Ms Moss, who worked in the cafeteria, to a position as a code clerk handling classified messages in the Pentagon. In McCarthy's questioning, he asks her if she's ever been a dues paying member of the Communist Party (no), whether she subscribes to the Daily Worker newspaper (no), has attended Communist party meetings (no), and so on (no,no,no). She's not very convincing in the film clips when giving her testimony, and the folks at CBS try to convince themselves that maybe one of the other Mosses in the phone book is the party in question (false). She is patronisingly presented as someone so simple as to have difficulty reading, but reading her job description reveals that she would have to be very much on the ball to fulfill the duties assigned. Four years later, of course, all the testimony she has given under oath is shown to be false (but not in the movie), and one wonders indeed who did promote Ms Moss, and why.The case of Lawrence Duggan, journalistic mentor of Murrow runs through the film, with Duggan always looking worried and nervous, until he finally commits suicide.No wonder: he was a Soviet spy, as revealed later (but not in the movie).Edward Murrow seems to look very worried a lot of the time, too. What is the meaning of the furtive glances exchanged between Murrow and Duggan? Is Clooney trying to tell us something? Did Murrow know his friend was a Soviet spy?The release of the Verona transcripts of intercepted Soviet code in 1995 provided the evidence that most all of what McCarthy said was true, and most all of what his detractors said was not.With this knowledge, it would have been more prudent for Mr Clooney to tell the story in a more ironic tone, and not retell the same old legends for the benefit of those who like to hear them.Trivia: Check the background in the original film clips of the hearings for Robert Kennedy (yes, that Robert Kennedy) - he was the junior counsel on McCarthy's committee.Addendum: After reading the meticulously documented book 'Blacklisted by History', it is patently obvious that McCarthy was destroyed by the Administration for 'outing' the practice of giving security clearances to the most egregious spies who then permeated the government and who were permitted to continue in their positions for years or allowed to resign and transfer to another government agency, or perhaps the World Bank or International Monetary Fund or the UN. Even the FBI was helpless; all their warnings and investigative reports were largely ignored or covered up.Rule #1: do not be a whistleblower: you will be destroyed.How about a movie that catches up with the now-known facts? Now that would be interesting, but don't hold your breath waiting for it.

reviewText: GOOD NIGHT AND GOOD LUCK is not the first movie to attack the George Bush era in politics by indirect means.  In 2004 M. Night Shyamalan attacked the paranoia and fear of the outside world found in Bushism in his underrated film THE VILLAGE (which modeled itself on Arthur Miller's THE CRUCIBLE).  Couching criticism of current political regimes in historical dress has a long and celebrated history.As much as I root for any film that attacks a mindset that I find reprehensible--the idea that anyone who criticizes an administration is somehow less of an American or hurting the country--I was not as impressed with this film as many of its viewers.  I very much liked the message in attacking McCarthyism-Bushism (anyone doubting that Bush was the primary target needs to hear any interview with George Clooney on the subject).  I loved the look of the film, the black and white showing to maximum effect the host of cigarettes lit in the course of the film.  I enjoyed the rich and talented ensemble cast and especially loved the main performance by the enormously talented David Strathairn.  But in the end the script did not seem to me to be especially strong.  I felt little of the dramatic tension that I had hoped and expected to experience.  I felt that the script in the end lacked focus and sufficient tension.  It was nonetheless a very good film; I was hoping for a great one.I have been a huge fan of David Strathairn for years, even since I first noticed him in John Sayles's great film MATEWAN and in subsequent films by Sayles.  Few filmmakers other than Sayles seems to have appreciated his gifts and until this film few have given him the kind of role his talent would seem to command.  He neither looks very much like Murrow nor does he sound very much like him (unlike, say, Philip Seymour Hoffman who doesn't so much imitate Truman Capote as incarnate him, albeit in a much taller version), but he does summon the spirit of the man.  He has the same kind of moral seriousness Murrow always managed.  I also like the idea of summoning the ghost of Murrow, easily the most respected journalist in the history of TV, to confront the spirit of the times.  Murrow would not only have detested the Bush administration with every ounce of his being, he would have been outraged by the utter decay of journalistic integrity and a world in which FOX News was not an automatic joke.A minor point of personal pride:  I grew up in Arkansas and attended the John L. McClellan High School in Little Rock.  One of the few people with sufficient nerve to stand up to McCarthy was John L. McClellan.  The film features an extensive archival footage featuring a long interchange between McCarthy and McClellan, the latter obviously outraged by McCarthy's excesses.  If one looks carefully, one will see a very young John F. Kennedy sitting beside McClellan.
summary: An excellent piece of political filmmaking

reviewText: Using black-white film, director-actor George Clooney (who makes an appearance as `Fred Friendly') has audiences consider the dangers of an unrestrained government---and the important role truly independent journalists play in protecting democracies.After World War II, the 'red menace' was considered the next great threat to American democracy. During the 1950's, very few people wanted to appear as being for communism; subsequently it was thought that no measure was too extreme to end communism.Enter a politically calculating young Senator from Wisconsin-Joseph McCarthy. McCarthy quickly makes a national name for himself by announcing that he has lists of communists who are in government, and the nation needs to follow him if they want to stop 'them'.  Among them is Milo Radulovich, an Air Force officer who, after secret accusations about his patriotism were made and he refused to denounce his father and sister, was drummed out of the service.Because no actor was cast to play McCarthy's thankless role, the film reacts to woven-in vintage clips of McCarthy himself. This also saves Clooney and the rest of the cast on the off chance that McCarthy's few remaining admirers want to charge Hollywood with 'twisting' his words.Against McCarthy's witchunt, Edward R. Murrow had the conviction to publicly call the Senator on his actions during an episode of his talk show "See it Now". In 1954 the veteran news journalist openly challenged McCarthy's allegations of communism being entrenched throughout United States society, the Radulovich allegations had offended him because a servicemember was asked to attack his own family.  Effectively ending McCarthy's reign of terror upon the American people, that investigation also championed the constitutional rights of all citizens.Foreshadowing Watergate, Murrow also proved that dedicated and professional journalists act as a much-needed fourth check on government actions and power.He receives critical backup from CBS News producer Fred Friendly (George Clooney doing double duty) and executive William Paley (Frank Langella). These are moves which I honestly believe would not be duplicated in today's TV newsrooms even with everything that goes on during our own time. Despite public criticism about the `liberal media' these journalists are trained to avoid offending their corporate owners and caretakers. People of all political ideologies will continue finding Murrow's professional integrity refreshing because he was only committed to delivering the facts of a story.Clooney and the rest of the crew/cast did an excellent job with period clothing, music, and mannerisms (Robert Downey Jr and Patricia Clarkson are a married couple in an era when workplace marriages are formally prohibited `just because') but the film's powerful message easily resonates with the current issues in our modern society. I am really impressed with the time and care George Clooney gave to this film.
summary: Special news report: Murrow takes on McCarthy in this fall's must see film

reviewText: This movie will be attacked, and for all the wrong reasons. It will be interpreted as a piece of leftist agit-prop. It will be attacked for being filmed in black and white and entirely indoors. But these complaints should not make the potential viewer think that this movie is not worth the watching. That is incredibly wrong.GOOD NIGHT AND GOOD LUCK captures a piece of time which is rapidly moving from current events to history. This is sad. The great Edward R. Murrow's meritorious dedication to the integrity of journalism is fast fading from the American memory. And while GOOD NIGHT AND GOOD LUCK only examines one aspect of his long career, what an aspect it is! Murrow's pit-bull grip to bring down the infamous Joseph McCarthy was probably the highlight of his career. (Unfortunately, it also relegated both men to the "back row" of their professions, in the long run.) Some people have read about how political cartoonist, Thomas Nast, brought down Boss Tweed in the 19th Century. Some people remember how Woodward and Bernstein were an integral part of forcing Nixon out of office. But this journalist's contribution to restoring sanity to America during the 1950s is hardly remembered, and not at all talked about in schools (unless you take a journalism class--and that's maybe!)The performances are wonderful. Strathairn IS Edward R. Murrows: remarkably understated and still very intense. George Clooney, as Fred Friendly, is his perfect foil--very extroverted and constantly joking. It was good to see Robert Downey Jr. take such a serious role, again. His portrayal of Chaplin is the last serious thing I think he did. Jeff Daniels was perfectly cast as the tooth grinding stuffed shirt, and Frank Langella was on-the-money as the powerful William Paley, owner of CBS.My only negative comment concerns the amount of time spent on the love affair between Downey and Patricia Clarkson. It really leads to an anticlimactic conclusion. The time would've been better spent helping younger viewers with some more exposition and gathering more sympathy for Ray Wise's Dan Hollenbeck, who was as much a target of the McCarthy sycophants as anyone else. (I would have also enjoyed more time watching McCarthy being brought down.) Still, this should BY NO MEANS prevent from watching this important film. It may not fit into your political views, but GOOD NIGHT AND GOOD LUCK will definitely fulfil the film lover in you.

reviewText: I'm as against McCarthyism as the next fellow.  Unfortunately, this movie is slow-moving, and the black-and-white format fails to lend it the air of authenticity that the creators obviously intended.Like too many Hollywood films these days, this one takes itself pretty seriously, and this gets in the way of what could have been a pretty effective "Good versus Evil" story against McCarthyism, which was a genuine illness of the American body politic.  No matter how serious the subject matter, the purpose of this kind of film is to entertain and to tell an interesting story.  This seems to have been forgotten in the zeal to make a political statement.On a minor historical note, it was not "courageous newsmen" who brought McCarthy down.  It was President Eisenhower and the US Army who did that.

reviewText: ***1/2Although set in the past - at the height of the Army-McCarthy hearings of the 1950's - "Good Night, and Good Luck" has a great deal of relevance to the world of today. For in an era in which civil liberties are again under attack due to a perceived threat to national security, and political opponents are labeled as "unpatriotic" and "soft on terror" merely for disagreeing with the powers-that-be in the government, this film reminds us of just how precious and vital disagreement and dissent are to the health of a democracy. The modern-day parallels are never far from the mind of director and co-writer George Clooney as he tells the true-life story of famed CBS reporter Edward R. Murrow's courageous attacks on Senator Joseph McCarthy during the politically charged era known as the Red Scare.This film is reminiscent of "All the President's Men" in its austerity and lack of narrative adornment. Filmed in period-appropriate black-and-white, "Good Night, and Good Luck" spends virtually no time on exploring the personal lives of the characters, choosing instead to stay entirely focused on the drama at hand. This has both a positive and a negative effect on the film. On the plus side, the film doesn't become distracted by secondary issues or wander off into irrelevant narrative by-paths. Yet, the film has an almost hermetically sealed quality to it in that we rarely leave the highly insulated world of the CBS studios. As a result, the movie sometimes feels as it it's choking on its own lack of oxygen, not providing sufficient room for the characters themselves to breathe and grow. Morrow, the host of "See it Now" whose signature sign-off becomes the basis for the film's title, delivers his pointed speeches and the men and women around him debate the issues of the day, but we really don't get to know any of them as people in the way we would like (compare it to a film such as "Quiz Show" which did manage to bring a three-dimensional quality to its characters).What the film does do very well is to point out the hypocrisy at work in McCarthy's witch hunt tactics, for apparently he couldn't see - or perhaps chose not to see - that, in his squelching of dissent and his terrorizing of those with political views opposite to his own, he was aping the very Communists he claimed to be reviling, becoming an even greater threat to true American values than those he despised.The performances - particularly by David Straitharn as Morrow - are good, but the overall lack of characterization makes "Good Night, and Good Luck" more interesting as a history lesson and an allegory for today than as a full-fledged drama.
summary: historically interesting but a bit stiff and airless

reviewText: I came prepared to like this film It's about a turning point in American history when reason faced down dangerous folly. And "Good Night" got such good reviews. But the movie just didn't come to life for me.David Strathairn portrays not so much a serious Edward R. Murrow, as a ponderous, leaden one - weighted with a sense of unrelieved doom. He speaks in deep overcast. He walks stiffly down corridors as if walking his last mile.The best performance is turned in by Ray Wise as Don Hollenbeck, a member of Murrow's broadcast team who in fact was doomed, but who fought to put on a brave front. As he stands there, trying to be one of the boys, you can see how essentially isolated he is by his private demons.George Clooney directs some scenes in imitation of Altman technique. For swatches, the actors talk in rapid, overlapping dialogue. But it doesn't work here as it did for Altman. Instead of adding energy and layering to these scenes, the technique only needlessly drowns what's being said.Clooney made an uneasy mix of this film in general. It's part documentary, relying heavily on actual footage of McCarthy. And it's part drama. But the result is not a happy hybrid docudrama. The result is a fractured mirror.When I looked to Clooney's DVD commentary to perhaps polish down some of the sharp edges, I found only a distracting goofiness. The first couple of times Clooney interjects, "Look, there's the sexiest man alive," as he comes on the screen in the role of Fred Friendly, it may be sort of amusing. But his repeated self-mocking quickly gets old.My father bought our first TV set so that he could watch the Army-McCarthy hearings. I was too young to really understand what was going on, but I remember sitting mesmerized in front of the screen. Joseph Welch, Attorney for the Army, became my hero as he countered McCarthy's increasingly scatter-gun ravings with calm reproof. And I later had a sense of Murrow as a Lincolnesque figure, delivering plainly reasoned eloquence in the face of what could have been the madness of crowds.If you want to know about Murrow and his colleagues and their bravery, if you want to know what the McCarthy hearings were all about - go to the several excellent straight documentaries that are available. Go to videos of the original broadcasts. In this case, the documentary can stand on its own. It doesn't need to be dramatized.

reviewText: The so-called "Communist menace" was the battle cry of the "junior Senator from Wisconsin," Joseph McCarthy whose bluff and bravado was finally called by Edward R Murrow and his team of journalism pros on live television while millions watched. This fast-paced film, skillfully filmed in B&W;, using mostly headshots, and with cigarette smoke filling the air, is not only a lesson in history but in superb directing and acting.Although many of us remember what happened, it is still highly suspenseful with its clever use of silence and profile shots, while the live jazz music of Dianne Reeves gives the viewer a necessary break from the intensity of the film.This is a non-selfconscious movie that cares about only one thing: getting the story and the characters right. It plays like a documentary. Murrow's prophetic words of the doom of television as "the [impartial] fourth estate" of the government couldn't be more true today. Alas, there are no more Edward R Murrows and our current president (Bush) has been getting away with murder, due to cowardly media coverage, only explored lately on PBS's Frontline.This is a movie that can inspire a new generation of what journalism ought to be, and certainly what filmmaking can accomplish when intelligent minds come together.

reviewText: "Good Night, And Good Luck" is George Clooney's love letter to the America of his 1950s childhood as much as it is an anthem to the journalism of that era and its figurehead, Edward R. Murrow. The opening sequence, at an evening gala of wine, smoke, women of a sophisticated age and men of a professional dignity, reveals as much.Did adults enjoy themselves more in those days? Maybe, to the  neglect of their children, who became our Angriest Generation a decade later. Is this a shamelessly romantic picture? Absolutely. Does it immerse itself the complexities of Murrow's 1954 takedown of Sen. Joe McCarthy and his Communist investigations? Not really. But I enjoyed it as I would enjoy a well-made film that appreciated the sunny idealism Ronald Reagan in the face of his rotten politics. There are far worse things than a picture about serious people considering serious things seriously.Consider how Clooney and actor David Strathairn - excellent here - portray Murrow, host of the CBS news program "See It Now," as a man who reveres words so much - and trusts his audience to understand - he dignifies them. He tells his audience, in one episode of his news program of "See It Now,"that he will read from a paper so as not to be mistaken. Before technology ever overwhelmed viewers with visual clutter - we're to the point where Bill O'Reilly uses a graphic summarize his key points - content and image were married in a way that required clarity and eloquence. Murrow delivered commentary without putting quotation marks around it.While we get the gist of the McCarthy hearings, "Good Night, And Good Luck" does not have the budget or epic goals of "All The President's Men," "The Insider" to relive the experience. For 45 years McCarthy - shown in the movie through real footage as a sweaty, furious troll of a man, a squinty-eyed balloon about to pop - was remembered as a zealot bent destroying ordinary Americans (and a lot of people in Hollywood) for minor or nonexistent connections to the Communist Party. Then conversative author Ann Coulter, among others, launched a vigorous defense of his hearings. The footage Clooney uses doesn't leave much doubt to me that McCarthy was about ready to start carving numbers in his wrist like John Forbes Nash, but then it's selective footage. Books - including Coulter's - offer better examinations, as do the movies "Guilty by Suspicion" and "Citizen Cohn."Clooney is after the essence of living in slight paranoia. One CBS news anchor, Don Hollenbeck (Ray Wise) commits suicide, partially for the relentless criticism he gets for being a "Communist sympathizer" on TV. One of the men who is part of the "See It Now" team has to remove himself from the McCarthy project because his ex-wife attended meetings long ago. "We have to do this," Murrow says in reference to McCarthy stories, "because it cuts to right here in this room."A classy supporting cast (including Clooney, Robert Downey, Jeff Daniels, Frank Langella and Tate Donovan) portray a bright, committed news team, aware of Murrow's talent, command, and reserved leadership. Strathairn makes several acting choices in the way he smokes cigarettes - a manner of expression back then. And Clooney, as he showed in "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind," is a talented filmmaker in basic ways - camera placement, lighting, composition, creativity. He integrates footage from "See It Now," "Person To Person," old commericials and the hearing themselves. He also recreates the old Columbia music recording studios that were once next door to the news floor. He inserts a few 50s standards from these  sessions as scene transitions. The effect is poignant and elegant. So is his movie.
summary: A warm flood of American idealism

reviewText: This film is a brilliant piece of work. The acting, cinematography and all aspects of the project is set as an exposition piece for the showdown between two methods of crafting words and "truth". The  one thing I love to see is that the person's response to what happens usually indicates more about themselves than about the film; this is a "here are the facts" showpiece, now how do you feel...The reviews I have read tell me more about the reviewers than they do about the film. The film has highlights of some people who viewed certain truths, and wanted the exposition of the rights of the people brought first, and also, as shown in the last few moments of the film story, the rights of Habeus Corpus; this film is close to timeless, whiilst being placed in a certain period of history , its story is one for the world to know; the truth will come out, and what goes around certainly comes around.

reviewText: I've been slowly working my way through the Oscar class of 2005 and I saved this one for last. I thought it would be boring but I actually found it quite fascinating and would rate it my favorite of the group.The story concerns Edward R. Murrow and his epic battle against the communist witch hunts of Senator Joseph McCarthy. It takes place in the fifties, during the heart of the cold war, when fear of communism was at its greatest. Nobody was better than McCarthy at inflaming this fear and it is scary to think about how much power he was able to accumulate in the process. Putting an end to the hysteria required someone of unshakable courage and principal. Fortunately for us, Edward R. Murrow was such a man. He had become a national hero during World War II by reporting from London while [...] bombs burst all around him. Risking his career and reputation, by potentially being labeled a communist sympathizer, Murrow used his weekly television show to bring McCarthy's unjustified attacks into America's living rooms. It is a classic example of why we need a free press. Anyone wondering why we put up with a sensationalist, sometimes annoying media should see this film. The movie ends with a warning, with Murrow telling us that the press must never forget its primary role as informer rather than entertainer. This is a sobering observation, given how entertainment oriented and slanted much of the media has become.Murrow is played perfectly by David Strathairn, who deftly exudes Murrow's laser like attack on McCarthy. Strathairn looks like Murrow, he talks like him and he even smokes like him. Murrow was known to smoke on the air while he broadcasted to America. This film was directed by George Clooney and if it is any indication, I will look forward to his next project with great anticipation. Clooney, who up until now I have associated with shallow popcorn movies, has created something of great intelligence and maturity with this film. It not only addresses serious social issues but he gives us a taste of what life was like in our past. The music, clothing and old news footage make this as much a period piece as anything else. Like many actor-directors, such as Woody Allen and Clint Eastwood, Clooney puts himself into the film but unlike his colleagues he doesn't make himself the star. Clooney plays a nicely understated Fred Friendly, Murrow's producer and close friend. Clooney acts well, and so do Robert Downey Junior, Jeff Daniels and many others but in my opinion this was Strathairn's movie.
summary: Gave me a whole new respect for the press and George Clooney

reviewText: George Clooney's "Good Night and Good Luck" gets high marks almost entirely across the board - the movie looks and sounds great, reeks of authenticity, and has more affection for the newsroom than any movie since "All the President's Men."  But the movie lacks that head-to-head showdown that makes for truly great drama.I won't reiterate the hundreds of reviews that comment on the movie's stellar cast, cinematography, or timeliness - if you aren't familiar with those aspects of "Good Night and Good Luck," I'd probably also have to tell you who Harry Potter is. I will focus on the movie's main calculated risk - using actual archival footage of Joe McCarthy rather than an actor.  This choice gets high marks for originality and veracity, but it comes at the expense of drama.The Joe McCarthy of the old celluloids just isn't a quality foil for Edward R. Murrow, as played by David Strathairn.  The movie depicts Murrow lovingly, zooming in for dramatic close-ups and generally lionizing the man as the epitome of the good citizen-journalist.  Conversely, McCarthy comes across as flat, stilted, and a completely unworthy opponent.  While the name "McCarthy" is invoked several times in the movie with paranoia and revulsion, the archival footage of the man doesn't back it up.  It would have been a better choice to have an actor equivalent to Strathairn get an equally ominous cinematic treatment.This is in contrast to the decision in "All the President's Men" to have Nixon and his cronies virtually completely off-screen.  Nixon was an invisible presence in that movie, and was genuinely creepy.  It's also like the movie "Jaws."  There are a couple of flash-scenes at the end where Spielberg includes actual footage of a great white shark, and it's obviously smaller than the monster depicted in the movie.  Spielberg included it to show the shark turning quickly, which his big terrifying model could not do.  This shot, while accurate, isn't nearly as terrifying as the mechanical shark's other appearances.Accordingly, we are denied a great pay-off scene in "Good Night and Good Luck" where McCarthy's fortunes crumble around him.  Instead, we get the archival footage of the "have you no shame, Senator" moment, and it just seems a bit flat.Despite this quibble, "Good Night and Good Luck" is a fine movie of ambition and art, and deserves to be seen.  Check it out.
summary: Solid performances, great looks, but anti-climactic

reviewText: This is a timely, historcally accurate semi-documentary of a story that needs to be told and re-told while some of the principals are still alive. Demagogues (and their allies in the media like Jack O'Brien then and Ann Coulter now) who confuse dissent with disloyalty to subjugate and frighten the most gullible members of society? Yes, it was as true of Joe McCarthy in 1954 as it is of the Bush-Cheney crowd today.  This film cannot help but make you think that we are at the same crossroads today.  Using the actual film of McCarthy himself was a stroke of genius; this is the man Coulter and the right are trying to rehabilitate? Good luck with that; people are not quite so stupid today because we recognize the demagogues for what they are. Of course there was a real "Communist threat" back then, just as there is a real terrorist threat today. Real Americans like Ed Murrow then (he risked his life on the London rooftops during WWII, as opposed to Chicken Hawks Bush/Cheney/Medved, etc.) and Russ Feingold today understand that we cannot defend freedom abroad while destroying it at home. Both McCarthy and Bush weakened America; McCarthy's fear mongering diverted attention from the real Communist threat and, as Murrow pointed out, actually gave comfort to our enemies. Bush's lies about WMD's bogging us down in Iraq divert attention from the real terrorist sources around the world, thereby again endangering all of us."Come Senators, Congressmen, please heed the call"--not to mention journalists, if there are any still out there. Start asking the questions so that we won't have to be making a movie twenty years from now describing how the far right brought down American democracy.
summary: A Superbly Well Done Wake Up Call

reviewText: This first major directorial motion picture by George Clooney works really well. A good cast, and in particular David Strathairn as Edward R Murrow deliver excellent performances in this true story of Murrow's battle to expose Senator McCarthy's witch-hunt against mainly innocent people.The film is beautifully shot in black and white, which baring in mind this all happened in the 1950's is completely appropriate. It also meant that Clooney could incorporate real footage of McCarthy rather than using an actor, and this certainly adds to the authenticity of the film.The film is short (90mins), and perhaps a bit more time could have been spent exploring the misery that McCarthy inflicted on many people with his witch-hunt. However that is minor gripe for what is otherwise a classy piece of film-making.

reviewText: This George Clooney film is truly significant today. Had the film been in the theaters a few years back it would've seem to be about mistakes past. In  the present day however there are a lot of analogs with how the Bush administration handles the war on terror and the atmosphere it created in society.The McCarthy era with and the House Un-American Activities Committee were a period in time of extreme polarization in the US. Prior to the fifties there had been a lively debate in America about the place of socialism in American society. Where in Europe this debate resulted in a strong welfare state the US took another direction. Under pressure of the cold war and a much stronger belief in capitalism everything slightly associated with communism became suspect. Socialism was seen as a threat to the American way of life and had to be fought on all grounds. All though it was never illegal in America to be a socialist or communist, the McCarthy hearings made one an outlaw none the less. People in public life who were suspected of "red" sympathies found their lives destroyed when branded a commie. This happened not just to those in public life. While "commie" actors were vicariously hunted regular people suffered as well. Being suspected of communism meant the loss of work and becoming a social outcast.The analogs to this day and age are clear. With the strong line on terror and military action as an answer to that the Bush administration once again managed to create a big cleavage in American society. With his "you're either with u or against us" dogma the Bush administration has once again made everyone disagreeing suspect. In this day and age the government has anti-terror laws to back them up and create an atmosphere of paranoia. Although supposedly meant to protect American citizens already the anti-terror laws made it possible to incarcerate people without due trial on suspecting of terrorist activities or sympathies to them. Especially Arab-Americans have become victims to these laws but other American citizens as well. Peace movement have been infiltrated by intelligent services and authors or journalist have found it difficult to get their books and articles published out of fear of retaliation.In a clever move George Clooney steered clear of present day McCarthy-ism by making a film of a victim of the McCarthy-era. This allows him to hold a mirror to the face of America. Clooney shows us an era we've all begun to see as un-American. It's up to the audience to find the analogs with today. However in showing the paranoia of the McCarthy era the film only mildly succeeds. In the movie he chooses to show us someone who managed to stand up to McCarthy in a time the hearings were already heavily debated. Although the story is beautifully told and powerfully filmed Clooney could have made a stronger point by showing us how at the beginning of the era careers and lives were torn down. For those interested in that process I'd warmly recommend the captivating Philip Roth novel Married to a Communist.

reviewText: George Clooney's black and white feature is about journalist Edward R. Murrow's effort to challenge the methods of Senator Joseph McCarthy during the 1950's when he actively investigated and indicted members of the entertainment, media, and military industries for communist sympathies and Soviet membership. The film is decent and well acted, David Strathairn plays a very convincing Murrow, and Clooney's directing is competent. However, the film takes an entirely too simplistic moral view of its subject, it fails to acknowledge the paranoia of the period and has the benefit of hindsight. Additionally, the film makes CBS and Murrow's efforts more heroic then they actually were, Senator McCarthy certainly didn't have as much power as the entire CBS Corporation, and the journalists who brought him down weren't really risking as much as the film implies. Furthermore, McCarthy was not attacked until he investigated individuals with real power like high ranking officials in the military; the film fails to make this clear. An average work on the whole, but worth seeing none the less.
Title: N/A

reviewText: George Clooney's GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK is a beautifully looking movie.  It employs sharp, aesthetically appropriate black and white photography in order to capture the 1950s black and white television era, and to imaginatively incorporate period footage of Senator Joseph McCarthy and people related to the events for which he was famous.  The cinematography and editing is first-rate, a real feast for the eyes, and I enjoyed the Ella-esque mid-century Jazz score.  Clooney's movie is essentially a hagiography of the nearly humorless newsman, EDWARD R. MURROW, played so woodenly by David Strathairn as to make Pinocchio seem like Gumby by comparison.  (It may have been an accurate portrayal of his personality, but it doesn't exactly make for captivating viewing.)  There were a couple of nice performances in the movie, most notable is Frank Langella in the role of William Paley; he had some real charisma.Speaking strictly visually, the movie's a winner, but GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK opens in 1958 at a banquet given to honor the television news commentator, MURROW.  (It's one of those types of affairs that my dear departed friend, Marty, once referred to as "a bunch of ###holes patting themselves on the back.")  Of the many singularly wondrous works of Murrow that we're informed of, one is that "He threw stones at giants ... not the least of which, his historical fight with Senator McCarthy."  So, Murrow was David versus Goliath, eh?  As McCarthy's chief counsel, Roy Cohn, wrote in his great book, McCARTHY: "All we had against us was the White House, the administration, the Democratic party, and the Republican party."  Wanna talk David and Goliath?  So, enough about the movie's artistic attributes, let's talk FACTS since this is a one-sided demagogic attack on the dead Senator who was himself often labeled a demagogue by the print and broadcast media:Our 1958 honoree tells his audience we need to get off our collective rear end and "recognize that television in the main is being used to distract, delude, amuse and insulate us."  Well, guess what.  It was, and still is!  And so are magazines and movies ... just like THIS one.  GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK (GN&GL;) is simply more of Hollywood's Socialistic brainwashing of Americonned citizens.  (We are told in this movie that in the 1950s, Kent cigarettes filtered best; Liberace was giving thought to marriage; and McCarthy was slandering completely innocent people and ruining their reputations and their lives.  Each one of those statements is only as true as the next.)GN&GL; touches on the most famous moments in the McCarthy "Communist Hunt."  (He was looking for Communists who had infiltrated sensitive departments of our government and who were being protected from exposure and removal by highly-placed government officials.  Contrary to popular belief, he was NOT hunting witches.)  But unless the viewer is familiar with the history, he or she will not likely grasp the relevance of certain details.Murrow insists that "ninety-nine percent of the time", McCarthy is wrong about the people he names as being security risks.  Do you know what became of the 110 people in the State Department who McCarthy named before the Tydings Committee (but did not name publicly) as possible security risks?  (Pardon me, I forgot that you're an Americonned citizen.  Here's an easer question for you:  Who got kicked off SURVIVOR last week?)  Well, 81 of those people were eventually dismissed or resigned from government service due to their Communist affiliations.  Mr. Murrow, that's nearly 74% proven right, not 99% wrong!  (And here I thought I was bad at math.)Watching GN&GL;, the Americonned viewer will come away with the idea that the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) was falsely accused by McCarthy of being a subversive Communist front organization.  Yes, the same ACLU founded by Roger Baldwin, who served as its executive director for 30 years, and who wrote 12 years after founding the organization: "I seek the social ownership of property, the abolition of the propertied class and sole control of those who produce wealth.  Communism is the goal."  (Book: THE ACLU VS. AMERICA)  You may not have known this fact, but I'll bet you know who won the last American Idol competition.In one scene, we see McCarthy's Investigating Committee questioning the poor, old Black woman, ANNIE LEE MOSS, who was employed in the Pentagon's Code Room.  She denies ever having been a dues-paying Communist party member.  The Great Murrow makes a heroine of the poor beleaguered woman, insisting that it's a case of mistaken identity and irresponsible McCarthy charges.  What you WON'T learn in GN&GL; is that it was later proven using the Communist party's own records that THIS "persecuted" woman (who lived on R Street in Washington D.C.) had indeed been a dues-paying Communist.  Yes!  Watch GN&GL;, watch her lie, and watch Team Murrow defend her!The scene that nearly made me laugh out loud has Team Murrow fretting, anxiously awaiting with bated breath the morning edition of the New York Times to see whether or not their television attack on McCarthy the night before will meet with the approval of the ultraliberal but influential newspaper.  Yes, the stridently anti-McCarthy New York Times - THAT newspaper.  That's fairly analogous to tossing a bag of T-bone steaks into a kennel and then worrying that the dogs might resent it!But what of EDWARD R. MURROW?  Along with William Paley, he was a member of the COUNCIL ON FOREIGN RELATIONS (CFR), an organization whose principal founder, Edward Mandell House, wrote that he essentially favored "Socialism as dreamed of by Karl Marx."  House further wrote, "For a long time it had seemed to me that our government was too complicated in its machinery and that we had outgrown our Constitution."  (Book: PHILIP DRU: ADMINISTRATOR)  According to 16-year CFR member, U.S. Navy Rear Admiral Chester Ward, the primary goal of the CFR is "to bring about the surrender of the sovereignty and national independence of the United States ... to a one-world all-powerful global government."  This will be global, totalitarian Socialism.  (Book: KISSINGER ON THE COUCH)  Today, the CFR even offers an "Edward R. Murrow Fellowship Award" and the Time-Warner company, distributor of GN&GL;, happens to be a CFR corporate member.What did MURROW do besides fight McCarthy's attempts to expose Socialists hidden in our government?  He defended J. Robert Oppenheimer who was fired as a security risk after it was shown that he had lied about his significant monetary donations to the Communist party.  MURROW produced a highly complimentary "documentary" on Fidel Castro which aided the Communist dictator in his coming to power in Cuba.  MURROW was an ardent defender of convicted Soviet agent Alger Hiss, and of Owen Lattimore, determined by the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee to have been "a conscious articulate agent of the Soviet conspiracy."  MURROW also was a board member of the Institute of International Education, which encouraged young American school teachers to train at the University of Moscow.  (Book: NONE DARE CALL IT TREASON: 25 YEARS LATER)  Of course, you Americonned citizens wouldn't know any of this because you've been busy watching C.S.I. Miami.Shakespeare's Juliet said, "What's in a name?  That which we call a rose, by any other name, would smell as sweet."  Well, if it looks like a pink rose, smells like a pink rose, and is growing amongst pink roses, I don't care if it's called a "courageous newsman" or a David who "threw stones at giants", I say it's a pink rose.  (And I gotta wonder if GN&GL;'s writer/director is planted in that same garden!)  I've seen raw meat less "pink" than Edward R. Murrow was.If you wish to wake up and throw off the shackles that have brainwashed you, go to the home page (titled, "In The News") of thenewamerican I-net site, click on the word "Profiles" (near the bottom of the left-hand column) and read "The Real McCarthy Record" by James J. Drummey.  If, on the other hand, you wish to remain an Americonned citizen, then just go back to your episodes of Buffy The Vampire Slayer.
summary: ARE YOU NOW OR HAVE YOU EVER BEEN A BRAINWASHED AMERICAN?

reviewText: This is a story about a group of people who see something wrong and have the courage to do something about it, even at great personal and professional risk. Unable to sit idly by while Senator McCarthy publicly crucifies a soldier and his family for allegedly having shadowy connections to Communism, Edward R. Murrow (David Strathairn), his producer Fred Friendly (George Clooney) and the rest of their CBS crew decide to take on McCarthy by questioning his motives and methods on air... You'd hope such a story wouldn't be so novel today. After all, the events the film narrates occurred fifty years ago. But with media increasingly controlled by large corporate interests, it's refreshing to see a film like Clooney's which shows what can happen when people have the balls to ask the questions everyone else is too terrified to ask. Beyond the thematic, this film is technically brilliant. The most impressive things about Clooney's writing and direction here are how efficient and thoughtful they are: the use of jazz from the next studio is not only historically accurate, but perfectly establishes the time, place and mood; the use of real footage, especially of McCarthy himself, is more powerful and more credible than any performance could have been. This isn't a long film. It isn't self-indulgent. It's short, quiet and contained. Given the subject matter it could so easily have been bombastic, didactic, even melodramatic. It isn't, and it doesn't need to be. Clooney grounds it in the personal lives and interactions of the news crew, making it less abstract and more human and thereby more moving. His case is perfectly clear: rather than trusting those who wrap themselves in the flag, stir up fear, and point the finger without evidence - things we've seen a lot of lately - we must demand such actions be defended and explained. Ultimately, Clooney's argument is about the power of television to be instrumental in doing just that. Pity it so often isn't.
summary: Essay on the power of television

reviewText: Good Night and Good Luck uses two plots to try to prove the idea that civil liberties must be defended at all cost. One plot is a reporter's external quest to defeat Mccarthyism: the violation of civil liberties in the name of national security. This plot succeeds: Mccarthyism is defeated. The second plot is the external quest representing the reporter's career and well being. This plot ends in a failure. So the movie tries to demonstrate the idea that civil liberties must be defended at all cost by showing that the successful defense of civil liberties cost our heroes their jobs, careers, and even their lives.This idea is a timely one for us: today the world is captivated by the tales of Edward Snowden: an ex-CIA worker who has given up his career and possibly his life to reveal massive violations of the civil liberties of all Americans by their government. As of now, we don't know how this story ends. We don't know if the cost of his sacrifice was enough to earn a "success" of protecting our civil liberties. What we do know is that the US government, and much of the public, believe that it is necessary to give up certain civil liberties in the name of national security. What this movie tries to demonstrate is that the US Constitution is built upon the idea that basic freedoms cannot be compromised at all, and that they must be defended to the death. As our hero says:"We can deny our heritage and our history but we cannot escape responsibility for the result. We proclaim ourselves as indeed we are, the defenders of freedom wherever it continues to exist in the world. But we cannot defend freedom abroad by deserting it at home. The actions of the Junior Senator from Wisconsin have caused alarm and dismay amongst our allies abroad and given considerable comfort to our enemies. And whose fault is that? Not really his, he didn't create this situation of fear, he merely exploited it, and rather successfully. Cassius was right, the fault dear Brutus is not in our stars, but in ourselves. Good night, and good luck."So the movie picked a very important idea to prove. Unfortunately, it doesn't do a very good job of proving it.The plot depicting the cost of our heroes is bland. There are no uplifting turning points on this plot. The heroes lose money, security, their jobs, the lives and their careers in a steady drumbeat of bad news. Because there are no twists and turns along the ride of this plot, the costs seem episodic and didactic. This makes the heroes seem flat and unreasonably "good" as they continue their march against the villains irregardless of casualties and consequence. Basically there aren't enough twists here to keep the story interesting. None of the heroes undergo internal arcs (they are all conscientious from start to end) and none of them undergo relationship arcs (they are all in it together from beginning to end, even a married couple who were forced to split up).This make the film seem didactic: it is a series of self righteous speeches by our heroes against the villains and we are asked to watch the movie with the hindsight of history to see their actions in the proper moral light.Ironically, the Snowden story playing out today has more interesting twists and drama than Good Night and Good Luck:- we don't yet know if Snowden will be successful in convincing the American people to defend their own freedoms.- Snowden has obviously acknowledged and accepted the costs to his career and possibly his life.- Snowden's internal ideals are tested enormously now: he has ironically sought political asylum from countries that have horrendous human rights track records as compared to the USA. This has already compromised his public reputation and may affect the outcome of his external quest as he could become an international political pawn.President Obama has even acknowledged in a condescending manner that the Snowden story might make a "TV movie" someday as he tries to convince the American people that civil liberties must be "balanced" with national security. Depending on how Snowden's internal struggles and his external quest turn out, his story just might prove the idea that civil liberties cannot be compromised at all and must be defended to the death.My Story Chart of the movie is at storycharts.ca
summary: Civil liberties must be defended at all cost
